HOW TO WIN PEOPLE TO YOUR WAY OF THINKING
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 128 | bei Position 1690-1691 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:26:46

I have come to the conclusion that there is only one way under high heaven to get the best of an argument—and that is to avoid it.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 128 | bei Position 1692-1693 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:26:59

Nine times out of ten, an argument ends with each of the contestants more firmly convinced than ever that he is absolutely right.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 128 | bei Position 1693-1697 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:27:35

You can’t win an argument. You can’t because if you lose it, you lose it; and if you win it, you lose it. Why? Well, suppose you triumph over the other man and shoot his argument full of holes and prove that he is non compos mentis. Then what? You will feel fine. But what about him? You have made him feel inferior. You have hurt his pride. He will resent your triumph. And – A man convinced against his will
Is of the same opinion still.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 129 | bei Position 1713-1714 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:30:24

As wise old Ben Franklin used to say: If you argue and rankle and contradict, you may achieve a victory sometimes; but it will be an empty victory because you will never get your opponent’s good will.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 130 | bei Position 1714-1716 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:30:38

So figure it out for yourself. Which would you rather have, an academic, theatrical victory or a person’s good will? You can seldom have both.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 130 | bei Position 1719-1720 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:31:33

You may be right, dead right, as you speed along in your argument; but as far as changing another’s mind is concerned, you will probably be just as futile as if you were wrong.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 131 | bei Position 1734-1736 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:33:30

Buddha said: ‘Hatred is never ended by hatred but by love,’ and a misunderstanding is never ended by an argument but by tact, diplomacy, conciliation and a sympathetic desire to see the other person’s viewpoint.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 131 | bei Position 1742-1744 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:34:45

Welcome the disagreement. Remember the slogan, ‘When two partners always agree, one of them is not necessary.’ If there is some point you haven’t thought about, be thankful if it is brought to your attention. Perhaps this disagreement is your opportunity to be corrected before you make a serious mistake.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1744-1746 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:05

Distrust your first instinctive impression. Our first natural reaction in a disagreeable situation is to be defensive. Be careful. Keep calm and watch out for your first reaction. It may be you at your worst, not your best.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1746-1747 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:12

Control your temper. Remember, you can measure the size of a person by what makes him or her angry.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1747-1749 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:24

Listen first. Give your opponents a chance to talk. Let them finish. Do not resist, defend or debate. This only raises barriers. Try to build bridges of understanding. Don’t build higher barriers of misunderstanding.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1749-1750 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:33

Look for areas of agreement. When you have heard your opponents out, dwell first on the points and areas on which you agree.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 131 | bei Position 1741-1742 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:40

how to keep a disagreement from becoming an argument:
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1750-1751 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:36:51

Be honest. Look for areas where you can admit error and say so. Apologize for your mistakes. It will help disarm your opponents and reduce defensiveness.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1751-1754 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:37:13

Promise to think over your opponents’ ideas and study them carefully. And mean it. Your opponents may be right. It is a lot easier at this stage to agree to think about their points than to move rapidly ahead and find yourself in a position where your opponents can say: ‘We tried to tell you, but you wouldn’t listen.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1754-1756 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:37:23

Thank your opponents sincerely for their interest. Anyone who takes the time to disagree with you is interested in the same things you are. Think of them as people who really want to help you, and you may turn your opponents into friends.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1756-1758 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:37:40

Postpone action to give both sides time to think through the problem. Suggest that a new meeting be held later that day or the next day, when all the facts may be brought to bear. In preparation for this meeting, ask yourself some hard questions:
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 133 | bei Position 1758-1761 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:37:49

Could my opponents be right? Partly right? Is there truth or merit in their position or argument? Is my reaction one that will relieve the problem, or will it just relieve any frustration? Will my reaction drive my opponents further away or draw them closer to me? Will my reaction elevate the estimation good people have of me? Will I win or lose? What price will I have to pay if I win? If I am quiet about it, will the disagreement blow over? Is this difficult situation an opportunity for me?
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 133 | bei Position 1764-1765 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 5. März 2021 22:38:13

PRINCIPLE 1 The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 134 | bei Position 1771-1779 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:16:56

When Theodore Roosevelt was in the White House, he confessed that if he could be right 75 percent of the time, he would reach the highest measure of his expectation. If that was the highest rating that one of the most distinguished men of the twentieth century could hope to obtain, what about you and me? If you can be sure of being right only 55 percent of the time, you can go down to Wall Street and make a million dollars a day. If you can’t be sure of being right even 55 percent of the time, why should you tell other people they are wrong? You can tell people they are wrong by a look or an intonation or a gesture just as eloquently as you can in words— and if you tell them they are wrong, do you make them want to agree with you? Never! For you have struck a direct blow at their intelligence, judgement, pride and self-respect. That will make them want to strike back. But it will never make them want to change their minds. You may then hurl at them all the logic of a Plato or an Immanuel Kant, but you will not alter their opinions, for you have hurt their feelings.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 134 | bei Position 1779-1780 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:17:15

Never begin by announcing ‘I am going to prove so-and- so to you.’ That’s bad. That’s tantamount to saying: ‘I’m smarter than you are. I’m going to tell you a thing or two and make you change your mind.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 134 | bei Position 1780-1781 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:17:29

That is a challenge. It arouses opposition and makes the listener want to battle with you before you even start.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 135 | bei Position 1793-1795 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:19:58

so I have quit telling people they are wrong. And I find that it pays. If a person makes a statement that you think is wrong—  yes, even that you know is wrong—isn’t it better to begin by saying: ‘Well, now, look. I thought otherwise but I may be wrong. I frequently am. And if I am wrong, I want to be put right. Let’s examine the facts.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 134 | bei Position 1782-1783 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:20:09

If you are going to prove anything, don’t let anybody know it. Do it so subtly, so adroitly, that no one will feel that you are doing it.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 135 | bei Position 1795-1797 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:20:22

There’s magic, positive magic, in such phrases as: ‘I may be wrong, I frequently am. Let’s examine the facts.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 136 | bei Position 1806-1808 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:22:52

You will never get into trouble by admitting that you may be wrong. That will stop all argument and inspire your opponent to be just as fair and open and broad-minded as you are. It will make him want to admit that he, too, may be wrong.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 137 | bei Position 1816-1818 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:24:59

Few people are logical. Most of us are prejudiced and biased. Most of us are blighted with preconceived notions, with jealousy, suspicion, fear, envy and pride. And most citizens don’t want to change their minds
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 138 | bei Position 1830-1832 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:26:56

I have found it of enormous value when I can permit myself to understand the other person. The way in which I have worded this statement may seem strange to you. Is it necessary to permit oneself to understand another? I think it is. Our first reaction to most of the statements (which we hear from other people) is an evaluation or judgment, rather than an understanding of
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 138 | bei Position 1830-1832 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:27:03

I have found it of enormous value when I can permit myself to understand the other person. The way in which I have worded this statement may seem strange to you. Is it necessary to permit oneself to understand another? I think it is. Our first reaction to most of the statements (which we hear from other people) is an evaluation or judgment, rather than an understanding of it.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 138 | bei Position 1843-1845 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 6. März 2021 22:28:37

When we are wrong, we may admit it to ourselves. And if we are handled gently and tactfully, we may admit it to others and even take pride in our frankness and broad-mindedness. But not if someone else is trying to ram the unpalatable fact down our oesophagus.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 139 | bei Position 1848-1849 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:02:46

But did all this bitterness make Lincoln agree with Greeley? Not at all. Ridicule and abuse never do.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 139 | bei Position 1849-1851 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:03:07

If you want some excellent suggestions about dealing with people and managing yourself and improving your personality, read Benjamin Franklin’s autobiography—one of the most fascinating life stories ever written, one of the classics of American literature.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 140 | bei Position 1859-1868 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:08:25

‘I made it a rule,’ said Franklin, ‘to forbear all direct contradiction to the sentiment of others, and all positive assertion of my own. I even forbade myself the use of every word or expression in the language that imported a fix’d opinion, such as “certainly,” “undoubtedly,” etc., and I adopted, instead of them, “I conceive,” “I apprehend,” or “I imagine” a thing to be so or so, or “it so appears to me at present.” When another asserted something that I thought an error, I deny’d myself the pleasure of contradicting him abruptly, and of showing immediately some absurdity in his proposition: and in answering I began by observing that in certain cases or circumstances his opinion would be right, but in the present case there appear’d or seem’d to me some difference, etc. I soon found the advantage of this change in my manner; the conversations I engag’d in went on more pleasantly. The modest way in which I propos’d my opinions procur’d them a readier reception and less contradiction; I had less mortification when I was found to be in the wrong, and I more easily prevail’d with others to give up their mistakes and join with me when I happened to be in the right.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 144 | bei Position 1928-1929 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:15:03

In other words, don’t argue with your customer or your spouse or your adversary. Don’t tell them they are wrong, don’t get them stirred up. Use a little diplomacy.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 144 | bei Position 1921-1922 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:15:12

Dr. King replied, ‘I judge people by their own principles—not by my own.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 144 | bei Position 1930-1931 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. März 2021 08:15:25

PRINCIPLE 2 Show respect for the other person’s opinions. Never say, ‘You’re wrong.’

12​. ​​​If You’re Wrong, Admit It​​
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 147 | bei Position 1957-1959 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:17:43

That policeman, being human, wanted a feeling of importance; so when I began to condemn myself, the only way he could nourish his self-esteem was to take the magnanimous attitude of showing mercy.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 148 | bei Position 1962-1964 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:18:25

If we know we are going to be rebuked anyhow, isn’t it far better to beat the other person to it and do it ourselves? Isn’t it much easier to listen to self-criticism than to bear condemnation from alien lips?
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 148 | bei Position 1964-1966 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:18:50

Say about yourself all the derogatory things you know the other person is thinking or wants to say or intends to say— and say them before that person has a chance to say them. The chances are a hundred to one that a generous, forgiving attitude will be taken and your mistakes will be minimised
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 149 | bei Position 1983-1985 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:21:05

There is a certain degree of satisfaction in having the courage to admit one’s errors. It not only clears the air of guilt and defensiveness, but often helps solve the problem created by the error.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 150 | bei Position 1995-1996 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:22:50

Any fool can try to defend his or her mistakes—and most fools do—but it raises one above the herd and gives one a feeling of nobility and exultation to admit one’s mistakes.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 153 | bei Position 2039-2042 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:28:55

When we are right, let’s try to win people gently and tactfully to our way of thinking, and when we are wrong—and that will be surprisingly often, if we are honest with ourselves—let’s admit our mistakes quickly and with enthusiasm. Not only will that technique produce astonishing results; but, believe it or not, it is a lot more fun, under the circumstances, than trying to defend oneself.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 153 | bei Position 2042-2043 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:29:03

Remember the old proverb: ‘By fighting you never get enough, but by yielding you get more than you expected.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 153 | bei Position 2044-2045 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. März 2021 07:29:10

PRINCIPLE 3 If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.
==========

13​. ​​​A Drop of Honey​​
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 154 | bei Position 2048-2050 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:07:39

If your temper is aroused and you tell ’em a thing or two, you will have a fine time unloading your feelings. But what about the other person? Will he share your pleasure? Will your belligerent tones, your hostile attitude, make it easy for him to agree with you?
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 154 | bei Position 2050-2054 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:09:01

‘If you come at me with your fists doubled,’ said Woodrow Wilson, ‘I think I can promise you that mine will double as fast as yours; but if you come to me and say, “Let us sit down and take counsel together, and, if we differ from each other, understand why it is that we differ, just what the points at issue are,” we will presently find that we are not so far apart after all, that the points on which we differ are few and the points on which we agree are many, and that if we only have the patience and the candour and the desire to get together, we will get together.’
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 156 | bei Position 2079-2082 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:12:45

If a man’s heart is rankling with discord and ill feeling toward you, you can’t win him to your way of thinking with all the logic in Christendom. Scolding parents and domineering bosses and husbands and nagging wives ought to realize that people don’t want to change their minds. They can’t be forced or driven to agree with you or me. But they may possibly be led to, if we are gentle and friendly, ever so gentle and ever so friendly.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 156 | bei Position 2082-2085 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:13:02

Lincoln said that, in effect, over a hundred years ago. Here are his words: It is an old and true maxim that ‘a drop of honey catches more flies than a gallon of gall.’ So with men, if you would win a man to your cause, first convince him that you are his sincere friend. Therein is a drop of honey that catches his heart; which, say what you will, is the great high road to his reason.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 156 | bei Position 2090-2091 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:13:59

This friendliness on Mr. Black’s part did what friendliness always does: it begot friendliness.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 157 | bei Position 2094-2099 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:15:08

Daniel Webster, who looked like a god and talked like Jehovah, was one of the most successful advocates who ever pleaded a case; yet he ushered in his most powerful arguments with such friendly remarks as: ‘It will be for the jury to consider,’ ‘This may, perhaps, be worth thinking of,’ ‘Here are some facts that I trust you will not lose sight of,’ or ‘You, with your knowledge of human nature, will easily see the significance of these facts.’ No bulldozing. No high-pressure methods. No attempt to force his opinions on others. Webster used the soft-spoken, quiet, friendly approach, and it helped to make him famous.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 160 | bei Position 2145-2151 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:23:01

Years ago, when I was a barefoot boy walking through the woods to a country school out in northwest Missouri, I read a fable about the sun and the wind. They quarrelled about which was the stronger, and the wind said, ‘I’ll prove I am. See the old man down there with a coat? I bet I can get his coat off him quicker than you can.’ So the sun went behind a cloud, and the wind blew until it was almost a tornado, but the harder it blew, the tighter the old man clutched his coat to him. Finally, the wind calmed down and gave up, and then the sun came out from behind the clouds and smiled kindlyon the old man. Presently, he mopped his brow and pulled off his coat. The sun then told the wind that gentleness and friendliness were always stronger than fury and force.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 161 | bei Position 2151-2152 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:24:57

The use of gentleness and friendliness is demonstrated day after day by people who have learned that a drop of honey catches more flies than a gallon of gall.
==========
How To Win Friends and Influence People (Carnegie, Dale)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 162 | bei Position 2165-2166 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. März 2021 15:25:08

Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 383-387 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:48:07

There is one thing we can do, and the happiest people are those who can do it to the limit of their ability. We can be completely present. We can be all here. We can give . . . our attention to the opportunity before us. —Mark Van Doren
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 4 | bei Position 399-403 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:50:44

The methods I present here are all based on three key objectives: (1) capturing all the things that might need to get done or have usefulness for you—now, later, someday, big, little, or in between—in a logical and trusted system outside your head and off your mind; (2) directing yourself to make front-end decisions about all of the “inputs” you let into your life so that you will always have a workable inventory of “next actions” that you can implement or renegotiate in the moment; and (3) curating and coordinating all of that content, utilizing the recognition of the multiple levels of commitments with yourself and others you will have at play, at any point in time.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 4 | bei Position 408-409 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:51:28

A paradox has emerged in this new millennium: people have enhanced quality of life, but at the same time they are adding to their stress levels by taking on more than they have resources to handle.

Work No Longer Has Clear Boundaries
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 417-419 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:53:27

A major factor in the mounting stress level is that the actual nature of our jobs has changed much more dramatically and rapidly than have our training for and our ability to deal with work.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 420-426 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:53:54

“knowledge” work. In the old days, work was self-evident. Fields were to be plowed, machines tooled, boxes packed, cows milked, crates moved. You knew what work had to be done—you could see it. It was clear when the work was finished, or not finished. Increasing your productivity was all about making the work process more efficient, or simply working harder or longer. Almost every project could be done better, and an infinite quantity of information is now available that could make that happen. Now, for many of us, there are no edges to most of our projects. Most people I know
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 420-423 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:54:01

In the old days, work was self-evident. Fields were to be plowed, machines tooled, boxes packed, cows milked, crates moved. You knew what work had to be done—you could see it. It was clear when the work was finished, or not finished. Increasing your productivity was all about making the work process more efficient, or simply working harder or longer.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 425-427 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:54:55

Now, for many of us, there are no edges to most of our projects. Most people I know have at least half a dozen things they’re trying to achieve or situations they’d like to improve right now, and even if they had the rest of their lives to try, they wouldn’t be able to finish these to perfection.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 6 | bei Position 431-432 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 20. März 2021 22:56:36

On another front, the lack of edges can create more work for everyone.

The Big Picture vs. the Nitty-Gritty
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 10 | bei Position 501-502 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:22:27

the well-intentioned exercise of values thinking too often does not achieve its desired results.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 10 | bei Position 504-511 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:23:05

There is too much distraction at the day-to-day, hour-to-hour level of commitments to allow for appropriate focus on the higher levels. 2  |  Ineffective personal organizational systems create huge subconscious resistance to undertaking even bigger projects and goals that will likely not be managed well, and that will in turn cause even more distraction and stress. 3  |  When loftier levels and values actually are clarified, it raises the bar of our standards, making us notice that much more that needs changing. We are already having a serious negative reaction to the overwhelming number of things we have to do. And what created much of the work that’s on those lists in the first place? Our values!
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 10 | bei Position 511-512 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:23:38

Focusing on primary outcomes and values is a critical exercise, certainly. It provides needed criteria for making sometimes-difficult choices about what to stop doing, as well as what most ought to have our attention amid our excess of options.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 10 | bei Position 516-517 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:24:17

The “Mind Like Water” Simile
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 544-548 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:28:41

Imagine throwing a pebble into a still pond. How does the water respond? The answer is, totally appropriately to the force and mass of the input; then it returns to calm. It doesn’t overreact or underreact. Your ability to generate power is directly proportional to your ability to relax.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 548-549 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:29:01

Water is what it is, and does what it does. It can overwhelm, but it’s not overwhelmed. It can be still, but it is not impatient. It can be forced to change course, but it is not frustrated.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 13 | bei Position 556-556 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:30:05

==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 13 | bei Position 563-564 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:31:45

That’s where the methodology of Getting Things Done will have the greatest impact on your life, by showing you how to get back to mind like water, with all your resources and faculties functioning at a maximum level.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)

The Principle: Dealing Effectively with Internal Commitments
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 13 | bei Position 568-570 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:32:25

A basic truism I have discovered over decades of coaching and training thousands of people is that most stress they experience comes from inappropriately managed commitments they make or accept.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 13 | bei Position 571-574 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:32:57

You’ve probably made many more agreements with yourself than you realize, and every single one of them—big or little—is being tracked by a less-than-conscious part of you. These are the “incompletes,” or “open loops,” which I define as anything pulling at your attention that doesn’t belong where it is, the way it is.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 575-577 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:33:17

Anything that does not belong where it is, the way it is, is an “open loop,” which will be pulling on your attention if it’s not appropriately managed.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 577-579 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:33:54

In order to deal effectively with all of that, you must first identify and capture all those things that are “ringing your bell” in some way, clarify what, exactly, they mean to you, and then make a decision about how to move on them.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 581-581 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:34:11

The Basic Requirements for Managing Commitments
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 581-582 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:34:29

Managing commitments well requires the implementation of some basic activities and behaviors:
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 583-584 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:34:43

Anything you consider unfinished in any way must be captured in a trusted system outside your mind, or what I call a collection tool, that you know you’ll come back to regularly and sort through.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 582-583 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:34:48

if it’s on your mind, your mind isn’t clear.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 584-585 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:34:59

clarify exactly what your commitment is and decide what you have to do, if anything, to make progress toward fulfilling
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 584-585 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:35:06

clarify exactly what your commitment is and decide what you have to do, if anything, to make progress toward fulfilling it.
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 585-586 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:35:19

once you’ve decided on all the actions you need to take, you must keep reminders of them organized in a system you review regularly.

An Important Exercise to Test This Model
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 589-590 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:35:39

write down the project or situation that is most on your mind at this moment.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 15 | bei Position 594-595 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:36:18

Now, describe, in a single written sentence, your intended successful outcome for this problem or situation.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 15 | bei Position 597-598 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:36:42

Now write down the very next physical action required to move the situation forward.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 15 | bei Position 606-610 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:37:50

If anything at all positive happened for you in this little exercise, think about this: What changed? What happened to create that improved condition within your own experience? The situation itself is no further along, at least in the physical world. It’s certainly not finished yet. What probably happened is that you acquired a clearer definition of the outcome desired and the next action required. What did change is the most important element for clarity, focus, and peace of mind: how you are engaged with your world.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 614-615 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:38:57

The Real Work of Knowledge Work
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 610-614 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:39:56

But what created that? Not “getting organized” or “setting priorities.” The answer is, thinking. Not a lot; just enough to solidify your commitment about a discrete pressure or opportunity and the resources required dealing with it. People think a lot, but most of that thinking is of a problem, project, or situation—not about it. If you actually did this suggested exercise, you were required to structure your thinking toward an outcome and an action, and that does not usually happen without a consciously focused effort. Reacting is automatic, but thinking is not.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 619-622 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:40:56

“In knowledge work . . . the task is not given; it has to be determined. ‘What are the expected results from this work?’ is . . . the key question in making knowledge workers productive. And it is a question that demands risky decisions. There is usually no right answer; there are choices instead. And results have to be clearly specified, if productivity is to be achieved.”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 619-619 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:41:11

Peter Drucker
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 17 | bei Position 624-628 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:42:00

We’re never really taught that we have to think about our work before we can do it; much of our daily activity is already defined for us by the undone and unmoved things staring at us when we come to work, or by the family to be fed, the laundry to be done, or the children to be dressed at home. Thinking in a concentrated manner to define desired outcomes and requisite next actions is something few people feel they have to do (until they have to). But in truth, it is the most effective means available for making wishes a reality.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)

Your Mind Doesn’t Have a Mind of Its Own
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 18 | bei Position 651-655 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 21. März 2021 18:45:42

Most people let their reactive mental process run a lot of the show, especially where the too-much-to-do syndrome is concerned. You’ve probably given over a lot of your “stuff,” a lot of your open loops, to an entity on your inner committee that is incapable of dealing with those things effectively the way they are—your mind. Research has now proven that a significant part of your psyche cannot help but keep track of your open loops, and not (as originally thought) as an intelligent, positive motivator, but as a detractor from anything else you need or want to think about, diminishing your capacity to perform.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)

You can think more effectively and manage the results with more ease and control. You can minimize the loose ends across the whole spectrum of your work life and personal life and get a lot more done with less effort. And you can make front-end decision making about all the stuff you collect and create standard operating procedure for living and working in this millennium.

The Value of a Bottom-Up Approach
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 21 | bei Position 709-713 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:49:44

Intellectually, the most appropriate way ought to be to work from the top down, first uncovering personal and organizational purpose and vision, then defining critical objectives, and finally focusing on the details of implementation. The trouble is, however, that most people are so embroiled in commitments on a day-to-day level that their ability to focus successfully on the larger horizon is seriously impaired. Consequently, a bottom-up approach is usually more effective.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 22 | bei Position 713-714 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:50:04

The Major Change: Getting It All Out of Your Head

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 23 | bei Position 741-742 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:55:37

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 23 | bei Position 742-743 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:55:48

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 23 | bei Position 744-746 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:56:14

The big difference between what I do and what others do is that I capture and organize 100 percent of my stuff in and with objective tools at hand, not in my mind. And that applies to everything—little or big, personal or professional, urgent or not. Everything.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 755-756 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:57:28

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 756-759 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:58:00

I try to make intuitive choices based on my options, instead of trying to think about what those options are. I need to have thought about all of that already and captured the results in a trusted way. I don’t want to waste time thinking about things more than once. That’s an inefficient use of creative energy and a source of frustration and stress.

if you made that kind of externalization and review a characteristic of your ongoing life- and work style, and you maintained it across all areas of your life (not just the most “urgent”), you’d be practicing the kind of mind like water management style I’m describing.

Getting Things Done (Allen, David)

Any “would, could, or should” commitment held only in the psyche creates irrational and unresolvable pressure, 24-7.

Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 761-762 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:58:53

And you can’t fudge this thinking. Your mind will keep working on anything that’s still in that undecided state.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 763-764 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:59:24

The short-term-memory part of your mind—the part that tends to hold all of the incomplete, undecided, and unorganized stuff—functions much like RAM (random-access memory) on a computer.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 764-767 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 08:59:43

Your conscious mind, like the computer screen, is a focusing tool, not a storage place. You can think about only two or three things at once. But the incomplete items are still being stored in the short-term-memory space. And as with RAM, there’s limited capacity; there’s only so much stuff you can store in there and still have that part of your brain function at a high level.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 776-777 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 09:00:54

A big problem is that your mind keeps reminding you of things when you can’t do anything about them. It has no sense of past or future.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 777-780 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 09:01:22

That means as soon as you tell yourself that you might need to do something, and store it only in your head, there’s a part of you that thinks you should be doing that something all the time. Everything you’ve told yourself you ought to do, it thinks you should be doing right now. Frankly, as soon as you have two things to do stored only in your mind, you’ve generated personal failure, because you can’t do them both at the same time. This produces a pervasive stress factor whose source can’t be pinpointed.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 26 | bei Position 783-786 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 09:02:03

Most people have been in some version of this mental stress state so consistently, for so long, that they don’t even know they’re in it. Like gravity, it’s ever present—so much so that those who experience it usually aren’t even aware of the pressure. The only time most of them will realize how much tension they’ve been under is when they get rid of it and notice how different they feel. It’s like the constant buzzing noise in a room you didn’t know was there until it stops.
==========

Getting Control of Your Life: The Five Steps of Mastering Workflow
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 791-793 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:36:48

THE CORE PROCESS for mastering the art of relaxed and controlled engagement is a five-step method for managing your workflow—the ever-present ingestion and expressions of our experiences. No matter what the setting, there are five discrete stages that we go through as we deal with our life, our work, and their consistent inputs and changes.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 801-803 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:37:27

(1) capture what has our attention; (2) clarify what each item means and what to do about it; (3) organize the results, which presents the options we (4) reflect on, which we then choose to (5) engage with.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 801-803 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:37:36

We (1) capture what has our attention; (2) clarify what each item means and what to do about it; (3) organize the results, which presents the options we (4) reflect on, which we then choose to (5) engage with.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 803-804 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:38:15

This constitutes the management of the horizontal aspect of our lives, incorporating everything that we need to consider at any time, as we move forward moment to moment.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 809-812 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:39:09

The method is straightforward enough in principle, and it is generally how we all go about our work in any case, but in my experience most people can significantly improve their handling of each one of the five steps. The quality of our workflow management is only as good as the weakest link in this five-phase chain, so all the links must be integrated and supported with consistent standards. Most people have had major inefficiencies in their versions of
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 817-820 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:40:48

Gathering 100 Percent of the “Incompletes”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 851-852 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:46:22

different than it currently is and that you have any level of internal commitment to changing.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 849-852 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:46:28

In order to eliminate “holes in your bucket,” you need to collect and gather placeholders for, or representations of, all the things you consider incomplete in your world—that is, anything personal or professional, big or little, of urgent or minor importance, that you think ought to be different than it currently is and that you have any level of internal commitment to changing.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 858-861 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:47:26

A task left undone remains undone in two places—at the actual location of the task, and inside your head. Incomplete tasks in your head consume the energy of your attention as they gnaw at your conscience. —Brahma Kumaris
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 861-865 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:47:59

As soon as you attach a “should,” “need to,” or “ought to” to an item, it becomes an incomplete. Decisions you still need to make about whether or not you are going to do something, for example, are already incompletes. This includes all of your I’m-going-tos, in which you’ve decided to do something but haven’t started moving on it yet. And it certainly includes all pending and in-progress items, as well as those things on which you’ve done everything you’re ever going to do except acknowledge that you’re finished with them.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 865-867 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:49:00

In order to manage this inventory of open loops appropriately, you need to capture it into “containers” that hold items in abeyance until you have a few moments to decide what they are and what, if anything, you’re going to do about them.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 871-871 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:49:17

Get It All Out of Your Head

Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 898-899 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:53:01

If you’re still trying to keep track of too many things in your mental space, you likely won’t be motivated to use and empty your in-trays with integrity.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 903-904 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:53:46

Keep everything in your head or out of your head. If it’s in between, you won’t trust either one.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 904-906 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:54:13

These collection tools should become part of your lifestyle. Keep them close by so no matter where you are you can collect a potentially valuable thought—think of them as being as indispensable as your toothbrush or your driver’s license or your glasses.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 906-907 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:54:24

The sense of trust that nothing possibly useful will get lost will give you the freedom to have many more good ideas.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 907-908 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:54:48

Minimize the Number of Capture Locations
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 908-908 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:54:59

You should have as many in-trays as you need and as few as you can get by with.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 908-910 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:55:22

You need this function to be available to you in every context, since things you’ll want to capture may show up almost anywhere. If you have too many collection zones, however, you won’t be able to process them easily or consistently.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 923-923 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:56:54

Empty the Capture Tools Regularly
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 924-925 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:57:05

if you don’t empty and process the stuff you’ve collected, your tools aren’t serving any function other than the storage of amorphous material.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 925-926 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:57:18

Emptying the contents does not mean that you have to finish what’s there; it just means that you have to decide more specifically what it is and what should be done with it, and if it’s still unfinished, organize it into your system.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 930-932 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 22. März 2021 22:57:53

In order to get “in” to empty, however, an integrated life-management system must be in place. Too much stuff is left piled in in-trays (physical and digital) because of a lack of effective systems “downstream” from there.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 937-938 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:25:04

Clarify
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 943-945 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:25:55

It is better to be wrong than to be vague. —Freeman Dyson
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 950-950 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:27:07

What Is It?
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 945-946 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:28:15

What do you need to ask yourself (and answer) about each e-mail, text, voice mail, memo, page of meeting notes, or self-generated idea that comes your way?
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 950-951 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:28:38

This is not a dumb question. We’ve talked about stuff. And we’ve talked about collection buckets. But we haven’t discussed what stuff is and what to do about it.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 956 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:28:54


==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 956-956 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:29:01

WORKFLOW DIAGRAM—CLARIFYING
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 957-958 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:29:09

Is It Actionable? There are two possible answers for this: yes and no.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 958-964 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:29:46

RequiredIf the answer is no, there are three possibilities: 1  |  It’s trash, no longer needed. 2  |  No action is needed now, but something might need to be done later (incubate). 3  |  The item is potentially useful information that might be needed for something later (reference).
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 958-964 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:29:54

No Action RequiredIf the answer is no, there are three possibilities: 1  |  It’s trash, no longer needed. 2  |  No action is needed now, but something might need to be done later (incubate). 3  |  The item is potentially useful information that might be needed for something later (reference).
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 964-966 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:30:23

For now, suffice it to say that you need a wastebasket and <Del> key for trash, a “tickler” file or calendar for material that’s incubating, and a good filing system for reference information.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 966-967 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:30:43

Actionable This is the yes group of items, stuff about which something needs to be done.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 969-972 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:31:13

Two things need to be determined about each actionable item: 1  |  What “project” or outcome have you committed to? and 2  |  What’s the next action required?
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 975-978 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:31:51

If It’s About a Project . . . You need to capture that outcome on a “Projects” list. That will be the stake in the ground that will keep reminding you that you have an open loop until it is finished. A Weekly Review of the list (see page 50) will bring this item back to you as something that’s still outstanding. It will stay fresh and alive in your management system (versus your head) until it is completed or eliminated.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 978-981 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:32:38

What’s the Next Action? This is the critical question for anything you’ve captured; if you answer it appropriately, you’ll have the key substantive thing to organize. The “next action” is the next physical, visible activity that needs to be engaged in, in order to move the current reality of this thing toward completion.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 983-985 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:33:05

These are all real physical activities that need to happen. Reminders of these will become the primary grist for the mill of your personal productivity-management system.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 985-990 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:33:34

Do It, Delegate It, or Defer It Once you’ve decided on the next action, you have three options: 1. Do it. If an action will take less than two minutes, it should be done at the moment it is defined. 2. Delegate it. If the action will take longer than two minutes, ask yourself, Am I the right person to do this? If the answer is no, delegate it to the appropriate entity. 3. Defer it, If the action will take longer than two minutes, and you are the right person to do it, you will have to defer acting on it until later and track it on one or more “Next Actions” lists.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 990-990 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:34:04

Organize
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 994-998 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:34:45

For nonactionable items, the possible categories are trash, incubation, and reference. If no action is needed on something, you toss it, “tickle” it for later reassessment, or file it so you can find the material if you need to refer to it at another time. To manage actionable things, you will need a list of projects, storage or files for project plans and materials, a calendar, a list of reminders of next actions, and a list of reminders of things you’re waiting for.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 1005-1005 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:36:34

Projects
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 1005-1006 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:36:42

define a project as any desired result that can be accomplished within a year that requires more than one action step.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 1007-1010 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:37:38

The reasoning behind my definition is that if one step won’t complete something, some kind of goalpost needs to be set up to remind you that there’s something still left to do. If you don’t have a placeholder to remind you about it, it will slip back into your head. The reason for the one-year time frame is that anything you are committed to finish within that scope needs to be reviewed weekly to feel comfortable about its status.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 1024-1025 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:38:30

You don’t actually do a project; you can only do action steps related to it.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 38 | bei Position 1027-1029 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:39:12

There may be reasons to sort your projects into different subcategories, based upon different areas of your focus, but initially creating a single list of all of them will make it easier to customize your system appropriately as you get more comfortable with its usage.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1029-1030 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:39:20

Project Support Material
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1030-1031 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:40:07

For many of your projects, you will accumulate relevant information that you will want to organize by theme or topic or project name.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1033-1033 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:40:39

Support Materials and Reference Files
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1033-1036 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:40:57

Once you have organized your project support material by theme or topic, you will probably find that it is almost identical to your reference material and could be kept in the same reference file system (a Wedding file could be kept in the general-reference files, for instance). The only difference is that in the case of active projects, support material may need to be reviewed on a more consistent basis to ensure that all the necessary action steps are identified.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1044-1044 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:42:07

The Next-Action Categories
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1044-1046 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:42:24

As the workflow diagram makes clear, the next-action decision is central. That action needs to be the next physical, visible behavior, without exception, on every open loop.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1046-1049 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:42:52

Any less-than-two-minute actions that you perform, and all other actions that have already been completed, do not, of course, need to be tracked; they’re done. What does need to be tracked is every action that has to happen at a specific time or on a specific day (enter those on your calendar); those that need to be done as soon as they can (add these to your Next Actions lists); and all those that you are waiting for others to do (put these on a Waiting For list).
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1049-1049 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:43:00

Calendar
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1049-1051 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:43:16

Reminders of actions you need to take fall into two categories: those about things that have to happen on a specific day or time, and those about things that just need to get done as soon as possible.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1051-1053 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:43:23

Three things go on your calendar: time-specific actions; day-specific actions; and day-specific information
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1053-1053 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:43:35

Time-Specific Actions This is a fancy name for appointments.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 42 | bei Position 1054-1055 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:44:01

Day-Specific Actions These are things that you need to do sometime on a certain day, but not necessarily at a specific time.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1059-1061 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:44:33

Day-Specific Information The calendar is also the place to keep track of things you want to know about on specific days—not necessarily actions you’ll have to take but rather information that may be useful on a certain date.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1067-1068 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:45:13

No More “Daily To-Do” Lists on the Calendar Those three things are what go on the calendar, and nothing else!
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1069-1073 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:46:08

First, constant new input and shifting tactical priorities reconfigure daily work so consistently that it’s virtually impossible to nail down to-do items ahead of time. Having a working game plan as a reference point is always useful, but it must be able to be renegotiated at any moment. Trying to keep a list on the calendar, which must then be reentered on another day if items don’t get done, is demoralizing and a waste of time. The Next Actions lists I advocate will hold all of those action reminders, even the most time-sensitive ones. And they won’t have to be rewritten daily.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1073-1074 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:46:20

Second, if there’s something on a daily to-do list that doesn’t absolutely have to get done that day, it will dilute the emphasis on the things that truly do.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1078-1081 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:47:18

That said, there’s absolutely nothing wrong with creating a quick, informal, short list of “if I have time, I’d really like to . . .” kinds of things, picked from your Next Actions inventory. It just should not be confused with your “have-tos,” and it should be treated lightly enough to discard or change quickly as the inevitable surprises of the day unfold.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1081-1082 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:47:57

The “Next Actions” List(s)
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1083-1083 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:48:09

Any longer-than-two-minute, non-delegatable action you have identified needs to be tracked somewhere.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1088-1091 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:49:06

If you have only twenty or thirty of these, it may be fine to keep them all on one list labeled “Next Actions,” which you’ll review whenever you have any free time. For most of us, however, the number is more likely to be fifty to 150. In that case it makes sense to subdivide your Next Actions list into categories, such as Calls to make when you have a window of time and your phone, or Computer action items to see as options when you’re at that device.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 1091-1092 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:49:23

Nonactionable Items
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1093-1094 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:49:44

Trash Trash should be self-evident. Throw away, shred, or recycle anything that has no potential future action or reference value.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1096-1096 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:49:59

Incubation
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1102-1103 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:50:49

There are two kinds of incubation tools that could work for this kind of thing: Someday/Maybe lists and a tickler system.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1103-1105 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:52:04

Someday/Maybe It can be useful and inspiring to maintain an ongoing list of things you might want to do at some point but not now. This is the “parking lot” for projects that would be impossible to move on at present but that you don’t want to forget about entirely.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1105-1106 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:52:11

You’d like to be reminded of the possibility at regular intervals.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1118-1119 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:53:02

You must review this list periodically if you’re going to get the most value from it. I suggest you include a scan of the contents in your Weekly Review
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1119-1120 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:53:36

You’ll probably have some other types of information that are similar to Someday/Maybe but that probably need a review only when you have an urge to engage in a particular kind of activity.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1121-1121 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:53:54

Books to read Wines to taste Recipes to try
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1124-1124 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:54:05

Tickler System
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1124-1127 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:54:38

A second type of things to incubate are those you don’t want or need to be reminded of until some designated time in the future. A most elegant version of holding for review of this nature is the tickler file, sometimes also referred to as a “suspense,” “follow-on,” or “perpetual” file. This is a system that allows you to almost literally mail something to yourself, for receipt on some designated date in the future.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 1127-1127 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:54:54

Your calendar can serve the same function.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1130-1130 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:56:21

Reference Material
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1130-1131 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:56:35

Many things that come your way require no action but have intrinsic value as information. You will want to keep and be able to retrieve these as needed.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1137-1138 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:57:40

The most important thing to remember here is that reference should be exactly that—information that can be easily referred to when required. Reference systems generally take two forms: (1) topic- and area-specific storage, and (2) general-reference files.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1141-1141 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:57:58

General Reference Filing
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1138-1139 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:58:07

The first types usually define themselves in terms of how they are stored
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1142-1143 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:58:53

The second type of reference system is one that everyone needs close at hand for storing ad hoc information that doesn’t belong in some predesigned larger category.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1145-1147 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 23. März 2021 22:59:00

The lack of a good general-reference file can be one of the biggest bottlenecks in implementing an efficient personal management system. If filing and storing isn’t easy and fast (and even fun!), you’ll tend to stack, pile, or digitally accumulate things instead of putting them away appropriately.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1149-1150 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:08:27

Reflect
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1152-1154 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:09:10

You need to be able to step back and review the whole picture of your life and work from a broader perspective as well as drop down “into the weeds” of concrete actions to take, as needed, and at appropriate intervals.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1154-1156 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:09:37

For most people the magic of workflow management is realized in the consistent use of the reflection step. This is where, in one important case, you take a look at all your outstanding projects and open loops, at what I call Horizon 1 level (see page 55), on a weekly basis.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1156-1157 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:10:09

It’s your chance to scan all the defined actions and options before you, thus radically increasing the efficacy of the choices you make about what you’re doing at any point in time.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1160-1160 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:10:39

What to Review When
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1160-1162 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:10:54

If you set up a personal organization system structured as I recommend, with a Projects list, a calendar, Next Actions lists, and a Waiting For list, not much will be required to maintain that system.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 1162-1164 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:11:19

The item you’ll probably review most frequently is your calendar, which will remind you about the “hard landscape” for the day—that is, what things truly have to be handled that day. This doesn’t mean that the contents there are the most “important” in some grand sense—only that they must get done.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1168-1169 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:12:14

After checking your calendar, you’ll most often turn to your Next Action lists. These hold the inventory of predefined actions that you can take if you have any discretionary time during the day.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1169-1170 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:12:26

If you’ve organized them by context (At Home; At Computer; In Meeting with George) they’ll come into play only when those contexts are available.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1170-1172 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:12:36

Projects, Waiting For, and Someday/Maybe lists need to be reviewed only as often as you think they have to be in order to stop you from wondering about them.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1172-1172 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:12:40

Critical Success Factor: The Weekly Review
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1176-1177 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:13:13

Everything that might require action must be reviewed on a frequent enough basis to keep your mind from taking back the job of remembering and reminding.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1177-1178 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:13:41

In order to trust the rapid and intuitive judgment calls that you make about actions from moment to moment, you must consistently retrench at some more elevated level.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1179-1180 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:13:56

All of your Projects, active project plans, and Next Actions, Agendas, Waiting For, and even Someday/Maybe lists should be reviewed once a week.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1179-1181 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:14:24

All of your Projects, active project plans, and Next Actions, Agendas, Waiting For, and even Someday/Maybe lists should be reviewed once a week. This also gives you an opportunity to ensure that your brain is clear and that all the loose strands of the past few days have been captured, clarified, and organized.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1185-1186 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:15:00

The Weekly Review is the time to: Gather and process all your stuff. Review your system. Update your lists. Get clean, clear, current, and complete.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1188-1190 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:15:17

Most people don’t have a really complete system, and they get no real payoff from reviewing things for just that reason: their overview isn’t total. They still have a vague sense that something may be missing.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 1190-1192 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:15:34

the more complete the system is, the more you’ll trust it. And the more you trust it, the more complete you’ll be motivated to keep it. The Weekly Review is a master key to maintaining that standard.
==========

Three Models for Making Action Choices
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1202-1204 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:17:41

Let’s assume for a moment that you’re not resisting any of your stuff out of insecurity or procrastination. There will always be a long list of actions that you are not doing at any given moment. So how will you decide what to do and what not to do, and feel good about both?
