1. The Four-Criteria Model for Choosing Actions in the Moment
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1211-1211 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:18:37

context, time available, energy available, and priority.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1213-1215 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:19:20

Context You are always constrained by what you have the capability to do at this time. A few actions can be done anywhere (such as drafting ideas about a project with pen and paper), but most require a specific location (at home, at your office) or having some productivity tool at hand, such as a phone or a computer.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1218-1220 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:19:42

Time Available When do you have to do something else? Having a meeting in five minutes would prevent doing any actions that require more time.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1220-1221 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:19:54

Energy Available How much energy do you have? Some actions you have to do require a reservoir of fresh, creative mental energy. Others need more physical horsepower. Some need very little of either.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1221-1222 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:20:13

Priority Given your context, time, and energy available, what action remaining of your options will give you the highest payoff?
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1224-1225 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:20:37

This is where you need to access your intuition and begin to rely on your judgment call in the moment.

2. The Threefold Model for Identifying Daily Work
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1228-1229 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:21:06

Doing predefined work Doing work as it shows up Defining your work
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 1229-1230 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:21:23

Doing Predefined Work When you’re doing predefined work, you’re working from your Next Actions lists and calendar—completing tasks that you have previously determined need to be done, or managing your workflow.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1232-1233 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:21:49

Doing Work as It Shows Up Often things come up ad hoc—unsuspected, unforeseen—that you either have to or choose to engage in as they occur.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1234-1236 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:22:21

Every day brings surprises—unplanned-for things that just show up—and you’ll need to expend at least some time and energy on many of them. When you follow these leads, you’re deciding by default that these things are more important than anything else you have to do at those times.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1236-1239 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:22:42

Defining Your Work Defining your work entails clearing up your in-tray, your digital messages, and your meeting notes, and breaking down new projects into actionable steps. As you process your inputs, you’ll no doubt be taking care of some less-than-two-minute actions and tossing and filing numerous things (another version of doing work as it shows up).
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1240-1241 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:23:17

Once you have defined all your work, you can trust that your lists of things to do are complete.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1241-1242 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:23:22

The final thing to consider is the nature of your work, and its goals and standards.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1242-1243 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:23:28

3. The Six-Level Model for Reviewing Your Own Work
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1243-1245 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:24:25

Priorities should drive your choices, but most models for determining them are not reliable tools for much of our real work activity. In order to know what your priorities are, you have to know what your work is. And there are at least six different perspectives from which to define that.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1246-1248 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:24:29

Horizon 5: Purpose and principles Horizon 4: Vision Horizon 3: Goals Horizon 2: Areas of focus and accountabilities Horizon 1: Current projects Ground: Current actions
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1248-1249 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:25:34

Ground: Current Actions This is the accumulated list of all the actions you need to take
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1250-1252 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:25:45

You’d probably have more than a hundred of these items to handle if you stopped the world right now with no more input from yourself or anyone else.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1252-1253 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:26:20

Horizon 1: Current Projects Generating most of the actions that you currently have in front of you are the thirty to one hundred projects on your plate. These are the relatively short-term outcomes you want to achieve,
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1255-1258 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:26:47

Complete the projects you begin, fulfill the commitments you have made, live up to your promises—then both your subconscious and conscious selves can have success, which leads to a feeling of fulfillment, worthiness and oneness. —John-Roger
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1258-1260 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:27:04

Horizon 2: Areas of Focus and Accountabilities You create or accept your projects and actions because of the roles, interests, and accountabilities you have. These are the key areas of your life and work within which you want to achieve results and maintain standards.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 1262-1263 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:27:40

These are not things to finish but rather to use as criteria for assessing our experiences and our engagements, to maintain balance and sustainability, as we operate in our work and our world.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1263-1264 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:27:49

Listing and reviewing these responsibilities gives a more comprehensive framework for evaluating your inventory of projects.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1264-1265 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:28:06

Horizon 3: Goals What you want to be experiencing in various areas of your life and work one to two years from now will add another dimension to defining your work.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1266-1268 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:28:23

At this horizon personally, too, there probably are things you’d like to accomplish or have in place, which could add importance to certain aspects of your life and diminish others.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1268-1269 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:28:42

Horizon 4: Vision Projecting three to five years into the future generates thinking about bigger categories: organization strategies, environmental trends, career and lifestyle transition circumstances.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1271-1272 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:28:59

Decisions at this altitude could easily change what your work might look like on many levels.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1272-1275 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:29:21

Horizon 5: Purpose and Principles This is the big-picture view. Why does your company exist? Why do you exist? What really matters to you, no matter what? The primary purpose for anything provides the core definition of what the work really is. It is the ultimate job description. All goals, visions, objectives, projects, and actions derive from this, and lead toward it.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1279-1281 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 08:30:04

Obviously many factors must be considered before you feel comfortable that you have made the best decision about what to do and when. “Setting priorities” in the traditional sense of focusing on your long-term goals and values, though obviously a necessary core focus, does not provide a practical framework for a vast majority of the decisions and tasks you must engage in day to day.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1285-1286 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:56:26

3 Getting Projects Creatively Under Way: The Five Phases of Project Planning
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1286-1288 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:56:51

THE KEY INGREDIENTS of relaxed control are (1) clearly defined outcomes (projects) and the next actions required to move them toward closure, and (2) reminders placed in a trusted system that is reviewed regularly.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1288-1288 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:57:04

This is what I call horizontal focus.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1289-1290 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:57:13

Enhancing Vertical Focus
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1290-1293 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:57:51

Horizontal focus is all you’ll need in most situations, most of the time. Sometimes, however, you may need greater rigor and focus to get a project or situation under control, to identify a solution, or to ensure that all the right steps have been determined. This is where vertical focus comes in. Knowing how to think productively in this more vertical way and how to integrate the results into your personal system is the second powerful behavior set needed for knowledge work.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1293-1296 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:58:08

You’ve got to think about the big things while you’re doing small things, so that all the small things go in the right direction. —Alvin Toffler
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1296-1297 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:58:58

This kind of thinking doesn’t have to be elaborate. Most of the thinking you’ll need to do is informal,
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1298-1299 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 22:59:05

==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1299-1300 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:00:31

once in a while everyone may need to develop a more formal structure or plan to clarify components, sequences, or priorities.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1302-1302 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:00:40

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1305-1305 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:01:56

The greatest need I’ve seen in project thinking in the professional world is not for more formal models;

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1306-1307 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:02:09

usually the people who need those models already have them or can get them as part of an academic or professional curriculum.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1317-1317 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:03:26

The Natural Planning Model
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1319-1320 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:03:41

You’re already familiar with the most brilliant and creative planner in the world: your brain. You yourself are actually a planning machine. You’re planning when you get dressed, eat lunch, go to the store, or simply talk.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1319-1319 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:03:51

You’re already familiar with the most brilliant and creative planner in the world: your brain.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1321-1328 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:04:04

Your mind goes through five steps to accomplish virtually any task: 1  |  Defining purpose and principles 2  |  Outcome visioning 3  |  Brainstorming 4  |  Organizing 5  |  Identifying next actions
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1331-1332 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:09:00

Your intention was your purpose, and it automatically triggered your internal planning process. Your principles created the boundaries of your plan.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1337-1339 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:09:15

That was your outcome visioning. Whereas your purpose was the why of your going out to dinner, your vision was an image of the what—of the physical world’s looking, sounding, and feeling the ways that best fulfilled your purpose.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1341-1344 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:09:35

That was brainstorming. Those questions were part of the naturally creative process that happens once you commit to some outcome that hasn’t happened yet. Your brain noticed a gap between what you were looking toward and where you actually were at the time, and it began to resolve that cognitive dissonance by trying to fill in the blanks. This is the beginning of the how phase of natural planning. But it did the thinking in a somewhat random and ad hoc fashion.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1348-1349 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:09:45

Once you had generated a sufficient number of ideas and details, you couldn’t help but start to organize them.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1350-1351 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:09:54

Once you’ve generated various thoughts relevant to the outcome, your mind will automatically begin to sort them by components (subprojects), priorities, and/or sequences of events.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1353-1355 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:10:13

This is the section of natural planning that incorporates challenge, comparisons, and evaluation, by its very nature. One thing is better, bigger, or ahead of something else.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 1355-1356 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:10:26

Finally (assuming that you’re really committed to the project—in this case, going out to dinner), you focus on the next action that you need to take to make the first component actually happen.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1358-1360 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:10:48

You have an urge to make something happen; you imagine the outcome; you generate ideas that might be relevant; you sort those into a structure; and you define a physical activity that would begin to make it a reality. And you do all of that naturally, without giving it much thought.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1360-1361 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:10:54

Natural Planning Is Not Necessarily Normal
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1371-1371 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:11:42

There are likely to be at least some components of the natural planning model that you haven’t implemented.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1376-1378 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:12:41

Think of your purpose. Think of what a successful outcome would look like: where would you be physically, financially, in terms of reputation, or whatever? Brainstorm potential steps. Organize your ideas. Decide on the next actions. Are you any clearer about where you want to go and how to get there?
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1378-1379 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:12:54

==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1379-1380 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:13:00

To emphasize the importance of utilizing the natural planning model for the more complex things we’re involved with, let’s contrast it with the more “normal” model used in most environments
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1381-1381 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:13:07

When the “Good” Idea Is a Bad Idea
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1381-1382 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:13:41

Have you ever heard a well-intentioned manager or project head start a meeting with the question, “OK, so who’s got a good idea about this?”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1384-1387 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:13:48

Before any evaluation of what’s a good idea can be trusted, the purpose must be clear, the vision must be well defined, and all the relevant data must have been collected (brainstormed) and analyzed (organized). “What’s a good idea?” is a good question, but only when you’re about 80 percent of the way through your thinking!
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 1387-1388 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:13:59

Trying to approach any situation from a perspective that is not the natural way your mind operates will be difficult.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1392-1392 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:14:32

The Reactive Planning Model
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1395-1396 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:14:49

The unnatural model is what most people still consciously think of as “planning,” and because it’s so often artificial and irrelevant to real work, people just don’t plan.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1396-1397 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:14:57

==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1398-1400 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:15:18

What’s the first level of focus when the stuff hits the fan? Action! Work harder! Overtime! More people! Get busier! And a lot of stressed-out people are thrown at the situation.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1400-1401 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:15:36

Then, when having a lot of busy people banging into each other doesn’t resolve the situation, someone gets more sophisticated and says, “We need to get organized
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1405-1406 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:15:56

Now someone (much more sophisticated) suggests that more creativity is needed. “Let’s brainstorm!”

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1407-1409 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:16:23

Time to hire a consultant! Of course, if the consultant is worth his salt, at some point he is probably going to ask the big question: “So, what are you really trying to do here, anyway?” (vision, purpose).

Natural Planning Techniques: The Five Phases
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1413-1413 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 24. März 2021 23:17:01

Purpose
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1413-1414 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 01:06:01

Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1419-1422 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 01:06:30

I admit it: this is nothing but advanced common sense. To know and to be clear about the purpose of any activity are prime directives for appropriate focus, creative development, and cooperation. But it’s common sense that’s not commonly practiced, simply because it’s so easy for us to create things, get caught up in the form of what we’ve created, and let our connection with our real and primary intentions slip.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1427-1427 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 01:07:31

==========

It defines success. It creates decision-making criteria. It aligns resources. It motivates. It clarifies focus. It expands options.

It Creates Decision-Making Criteria
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1441-1443 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 01:10:43

Often the only way to make a hard decision is to come back to the purpose of what you’re doing.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1443-1444 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 01:10:50

==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1449-1451 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:20:58

Let’s face it: if there’s no good reason to be doing something, it’s not worth doing. I’m often stunned by how many people have forgotten why they’re doing what they’re doing—and by how quickly a simple question like, “Why are you doing that?” can get them back on track.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1449-1451 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:21:01

It Motivates Let’s face it: if there’s no good reason to be doing something, it’s not worth doing. I’m often stunned by how many people have forgotten why they’re doing what they’re doing—and by how quickly a simple question like, “Why are you doing that?” can get them back on track.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1451-1455 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:21:56

It Clarifies Focus When you land on the real purpose for anything you’re doing, it makes things clearer. Just taking two minutes and writing out your primary reason for doing something invariably creates an increased sharpness of vision, much like bringing a telescope into focus. Frequently, projects and situations that have begun to feel scattered and blurred grow clearer when someone brings it back home by asking, “What are we really trying to accomplish here?”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 1455-1456 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:22:36

It Expands Options Paradoxically, even as purpose brings things into pinpoint focus, it opens up creative thinking about wider possibilities. When you really know the underlying why
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1457-1458 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:22:41

it expands your thinking about how to make the desired result happen.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1459-1461 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:23:17

Is your purpose clear and specific enough? If you’re truly experiencing the benefits of a purpose focus—motivation, clarity, decision-making criteria, alignment, and creativity—then your purpose probably is specific enough. But many purpose statements are too vague to produce such results.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1463-1464 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 16:23:35

In other words, if you don’t really know when you’ve met your purpose or when you’re off track, you don’t have a viable directive. The question, “How will I know when this is off purpose?” must have a clear answer.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)

Principles
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1465-1468 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:01:34

Simple, clear purpose and principles give rise to complex and intelligent behavior. Complex rules and regulations give rise to simple and stupid behavior. —Dee Hock
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1465-1468 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:01:39

Simple, clear purpose and principles give rise to complex and intelligent behavior. Complex rules and regulations give rise to simple and stupid behavior. —Dee Hock
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1470-1471 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:02:17

A great way to think about what your principles are is to complete this sentence: “I would give others totally free rein to do this as long as they . . .”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1473-1474 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:02:41

It can be a major source of stress when others engage in or allow behavior that’s outside your standards.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1475-1476 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:03:00

You may want to begin by asking yourself, “What behavior might undermine what I’m doing, and how can I prevent it?” That will give you a good starting point for defining your standards.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1476-1477 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:03:30

Another great reason for focusing on principles is the clarity and reference point they provide for positive conduct.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1479-1480 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:03:50

Whereas purpose provides the juice and the direction, principles define the parameters of action and the criteria for excellence of conduct.
==========

Vision/Outcome
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1480-1483 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:04:26

In order to most productively access the conscious and unconscious resources available to you, you must have a clear picture in your mind of what success would look, sound, and feel like. Purpose and principles furnish the impetus and the monitoring, but vision provides the actual blueprint of the final result. This is the what instead of the why.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 1486-1486 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:04:45

Clarifying Outcomes
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 70 | bei Position 1511-1512 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:07:34

There is a simple but profound principle that emerges from understanding the way your perceptive filters work: you won’t see how to do it until you see yourself doing it.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 70 | bei Position 1514-1517 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:08:02

It’s easy to envision something happening if it has happened before or you have had experience with similar successes. It can be quite a challenge, however, to identify with images of success if they represent new and foreign territory—that is, if you have few reference points about what an event might actually look like and little experience of your own ability to make it happen.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 70 | bei Position 1519-1521 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:08:31

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 70 | bei Position 1523-1524 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:08:54

==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 70 | bei Position 1528-1529 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:09:27

Outcome/vision can range from a simple statement of the project, such as “Finalize computer-system implementation,” to a completely scripted movie depicting the future scene in all its glorious detail.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1529-1532 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:10:02

When I am able to get people to focus on a successful scenario of their project, they usually experience heightened enthusiasm and think of something unique and positive about it that didn’t occur to them before. “Wouldn’t it be great if . . .” is not a bad way to start thinking about a situation, at least for long enough to have the option of getting an answer.
==========

Brainstorming
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1535-1537 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:10:30

When you identify with some picture in your mind that is different from your current reality, you automatically start filling in the gaps, or brainstorming.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1537-1538 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:10:45

This process usually goes on internally for most people about most things, and that’s often sufficient.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1539-1540 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:11:02

==========

Capturing Your Ideas
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1546-1547 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:11:45

If nothing else (and there is plenty of “else”), this practice adds to your efficiency—when you have the idea, you grab it, which means you won’t have to have the idea again.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1544-1545 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:11:54

Although the authors of these various processes may portray them as being different from one another, for most of us end users the basic premise remains the same: give yourself
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1544-1547 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:12:04

Although the authors of these various processes may portray them as being different from one another, for most of us end users the basic premise remains the same: give yourself permission to capture and express any idea, and then later on figure out how it fits in and what to do with it. If nothing else (and there is plenty of “else”), this practice adds to your efficiency—when you have the idea, you grab it, which means you won’t have to have the idea again.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1555-1555 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:13:00

Distributed Cognition
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1555-1557 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:13:14

The great thing about external brainstorming is that in addition to capturing your original ideas, it can help generate many new ones that might not have occurred to you if you didn’t have a mechanism to hold your thoughts and continually reflect them back to you.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1563-1564 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:13:51

It’s getting things out of your head and into objective, reviewable formats—building an “extended mind.”
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1570-1573 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:14:54

Few people can hold their focus on a topic for more than a couple of minutes without some objective structure and tool or trigger to help them. Pick a big project you have going right now and just try to think of nothing else for more than thirty seconds. This is pretty hard to do unless you have a pen and paper in hand and use one of those “cognitive artifacts” as the anchor for your ideas.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1575-1576 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:15:17

Brainstorming Keys
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1577-1578 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:15:27

Don’t judge, challenge, evaluate, or criticize. Go for quantity, not quality. Put analysis and organization in the background.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1581-1581 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:16:01

Don’t Judge, Challenge, Evaluate, or Criticize
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1581-1582 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:16:36

It’s easy for the unnatural planning model to rear its ugly head in brainstorming, making people jump to premature evaluations and critiques of ideas.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1584-1585 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:17:05

It’s also important that brainstorming be put into the overall context of the planning process, because if you think you’re doing it just for its own sake, it can seem trite and inappropriately off course.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1587-1589 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:17:35

This is not to suggest that you should shut off critical thinking, though—everything ought to be fair game at this stage. “Here’s what might be wrong with that approach” needs to be on the table, if it’s present. Often it’s the most challenging and critical ideas that have the germ of the best ones.
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1590-1591 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:17:48

Go for Quantity, Not Quality
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 74 | bei Position 1591-1591 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:17:53

Going for quantity keeps your thinking expansive.

Often you won’t know what’s a good idea until you have it. And sometimes you’ll realize it’s a good idea, or the germ of one, only later on.

Put Analysis and Organization in the Background
==========
Getting Things Done (Allen, David)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 76 | bei Position 1596-1599 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 26. März 2021 22:19:34

Making a list can be a creative thing to do; it’s a way to consider the people who should be on your team, the customer requirements for the software, or the components of the business plan. Der Name des Windes: Die Königsmörder-Chronik. Erster Tag (German Edition) (Rothfuss, Patrick)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 800 | bei Position 13118-13122 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 18. April 2021 02:06:14

»Es ist ein Wort. Worte sind die blassen Schatten vergessener Namen. Und wie Namen Macht innewohnt, wohnt auch Worten Macht inne. Mit Worten kann man im Geist der Menschen Feuer entfachen. Mit Worten kann man selbst dem hartherzigsten Menschen Tränen entlocken. Es gibt sieben Worte, die einen Menschen dazu bringen, dich zu lieben. Und es gibt zehn Worte, mit denen man den Willen selbst des stärksten Mannes brechen kann. Aber ein Wort ist weiter nichts als die bildliche Darstellung eines Feuers. Ein Name ist das Feuer selbst.«
==========

Doch etwas trotzdem zu lieben, die Fehler zu kennen und auch sie zu lieben: Das ist selten, rein und vollkommen

Da sie nicht unendlich klein sind, es aber unendlich viele sind, ist die Summe daraus wieder unendlich. Daraus folgt, dass letztlich jede Zahl unendlich ist.«

Am Rande der Schatten: 2 (Schatten-Trilogie) (German Edition) (Weeks, Brent)
- Ihre Markierung bei Position 2317-2331 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 15. September 2021 21:21:34

Wie kam es, dass sie die vierundachtzig Variationen des symbelinischen Gewebes meistern konnte, aber nicht imstande war, Konversation zu machen? Gewiss sollte leichtes Geplauder sich auf vielleicht einige hundert typische Fragen reduzieren lassen, die sich dann je nach den Antworten des Gesprächspartners, der eigenen Kenntnis von ihm, der eigenen Position im Verhältnis zu ihm und den gerade aktuellen Ereignissen zu Konservationsbäumen verzweigen ließen. Der richtige Zeitpunkt der Fragen und die Länge der eigenen Antworten würden ebenfalls studiert werden müssen, aber auch viele Schüsse des Gewebes verlangten eine genaue Bestimmung des richtigen Zeitpunkts, und Ariels Rhythmus war perfekt. Man musste vielleicht die physikalische Umgebung mit einbeziehen: Im Büro der Sprecherin würde man anders reden als in einer Taverne. Zu den Studienfeldern konnte die Frage zählen, wie man mit Ablenkungen umging, welches Maß an Blickkontakt oder körperlicher Berührung geziemend war, man konnte kulturelle Variationen berücksichtigen und natürlich die unterschiedliche Art, mit Männern und Frauen zu sprechen, unterteilt je nachdem, ob man selbst ein Mann oder eine Frau war. Ariel nahm an, dass man auch Kinder in das Studium einschließen müsste, und es wäre wichtig festzulegen, wie man mit Personen sprach, zu denen man in verschiedenen Abstufungen der Freundschaft oder des Interesses stand, sei es romantischer oder anderer Natur. Oder vielleicht nicht? Sollte man mit einer Frau, von der man dachte, dass man sich mit ihr vielleicht gern anfreunden würde, anders plaudern als mit einer Frau, an der man kein Interesse hatte? Gab es gesellschaftlich akzeptable Möglichkeiten, langweilige Gespräche abzukürzen? Diese Überlegung entlockte Ariel ein Lächeln. In ihren Augen wäre die Abkürzung langweiliger Gespräche ein gewaltiges Plus.
==========
Am Rande der Schatten: 2 (Schatten-Trilogie) (German Edition) (Weeks, Brent)
- Ihre Markierung bei Position 2411-2412 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 16. September 2021 20:55:56

Im Ernst. Bevor es eine Frau in seinem Leben gegeben hatte, waren die Dinge so einfach gewesen.

it is far from obvious that something as simple as a checklist could be of substantial help. We may admit that errors and oversights occur—even devastating ones. But we believe our jobs are too complicated to reduce to a checklist.

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 35 | bei Position 447-449 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. November 2021 00:04:28

In a complex environment, experts are up against two main difficulties. The first is the fallibility of human memory and attention, especially when it comes to mundane, routine matters that are easily overlooked under the strain of more pressing events.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 450-452 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. November 2021 00:04:46

Faulty memory and distraction are a particular danger in what engineers call all-or-none processes: whether running to the store to buy ingredients for a cake, preparing an airplane for takeoff, or evaluating a sick person in the hospital, if you miss just one key thing, you might as well not have made the effort at all.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 452-454 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. November 2021 00:05:03

A further difficulty, just as insidious, is that people can lull themselves into skipping steps even when they remember them. In complex processes, after all, certain steps don’t always matter.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 456-457 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 7. November 2021 00:05:42

Checklists seem to provide protection against such failures. They remind us of the minimum necessary steps and make them explicit. They not only offer the possibility of verification but also instill a kind of discipline of higher performance.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 592-597 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 8. November 2021 00:26:18

Four generations after the first aviation checklists went into use, a lesson is emerging: checklists seem able to defend anyone, even the experienced, against failure in many more tasks than we realized. They provide a kind of cognitive net. They catch mental flaws inherent in all of us—flaws of memory and attention and thoroughness. And because they do, they raise wide, unexpected possibilities. But they presumably have limits, as well. So a key step is to identify which kinds of situations checklists can help with and which ones they can’t.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 597-608 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 8. November 2021 00:27:51

Two professors who study the science of complexity—Brenda Zimmerman of York University and Sholom Glouberman of the University of Toronto—have proposed a distinction among three different kinds of problems in the world: the simple, the complicated, and the complex. Simple problems, they note, are ones like baking a cake from a mix. There is a recipe. Sometimes there are a few basic techniques to learn. But once these are mastered, following the recipe brings a high likelihood of success. Complicated problems are ones like sending a rocket to the moon. They can sometimes be broken down into a series of simple problems. But there is no straightforward recipe. Success frequently requires multiple people, often multiple teams, and specialized expertise. Unanticipated difficulties are frequent. Timing and coordination become serious concerns. Complex problems are ones like raising a child. Once you learn how to send a rocket to the moon, you can repeat the process with other rockets and perfect it. One rocket is like another rocket. But not so with raising a child, the professors point out. Every child is unique. Although raising one child may provide experience, it does not guarantee success with the next child. Expertise is valuable but most certainly not sufficient. Indeed, the next child may require an entirely different approach from the previous one. And this brings up another feature of complex problems: their outcomes remain highly uncertain. Yet we all know that it is possible to raise a child well. It’s complex, that’s all.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 49 | bei Position 609-609 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 8. November 2021 00:28:52

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 66 | bei Position 831-835 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:14:55

In the face of the unknown—the always nagging uncertainty about whether, under complex circumstances, things will really be okay—the builders trusted in the power of communication. They didn’t believe in the wisdom of the single individual, of even an experienced engineer. They believed in the wisdom of the group, the wisdom of making sure that multiple pairs of eyes were on a problem and then letting the watchers decide what to do. Man is fallible, but maybe men are less so.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 844-846 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:16:36

But it’s not enough to show the clash on the screen, he explained. You have to resolve it, and to do that you have to make sure the critical people talk. So the computer also flags the issue for the submittal schedule printout and sends an e-mail to each of the parties who have to resolve it.

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 896-899 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:24:53

There is a particularly tantalizing aspect to the building industry’s strategy for getting things right in complex situations: it’s that it gives people power. In response to risk, most authorities tend to centralize power and decision making. That’s usually what checklists are about—dictating instructions to the workers below to ensure they do things the way we want.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 73 | bei Position 904-906 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:25:34

The philosophy is that you push the power of decision making out to the periphery and away from the center. You give people the room to adapt, based on their experience and expertise. All you ask is that they talk to one another and take responsibility. That is what works.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 75 | bei Position 938-938 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:30:41

in the face of an extraordinarily complex problem, power needed to be pushed out of the center as far as possible.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 987-988 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:37:06

power to manage the nuances and unpredictabilities the best they
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 979-983 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:37:36

under conditions of true complexity—where the knowledge required exceeds that of any individual and unpredictability reigns—efforts to dictate every step from the center will fail. People need room to act and adapt. Yet they cannot succeed as isolated individuals, either—that is anarchy. Instead, they require a seemingly contradictory mix of freedom and expectation—expectation to coordinate, for example, and also to measure progress toward common goals.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 984-988 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:38:28

They had made the reliable management of complexity a routine. That routine requires balancing a number of virtues: freedom and discipline, craft and protocol, specialized ability and group collaboration. And for checklists to help achieve that balance, they have to take two almost opposing forms. They supply a set of checks to ensure the stupid but critical stuff is not overlooked, and they supply another set of checks to ensure people talk and coordinate and accept responsibility while nonetheless being left the power to manage the nuances and unpredictabilities the best they know how.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 988-990 | Hinzugefügt am Dienstag, 9. November 2021 22:38:46

I came away from Katrina and the builders with a kind of theory: under conditions of complexity, not only are checklists a help, they are required for success. There must always be room for judgment, but judgment aided—and even enhanced—by procedure.
==========

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 99 | bei Position 1236-1239 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 10. November 2021 23:48:24

But getting teams to stop and use the checklist—to make it their habit—was clearly tricky. A couple of check boxes weren’t going to do much all by themselves. So the surgical director gave some lectures to the nurses, anesthesiologists, and surgeons explaining what this checklist thing was all about. He also did something curious: he designed a little metal tent stenciled with the phrase Cleared for Take off and arranged for it to be placed in the surgical instrument kits.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 99 | bei Position 1240-1242 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 10. November 2021 23:48:32

This served as a reminder to run the checklist before making the incision. Just as important, it also made clear that the surgeon could not start the operation until the nurse gave the okay and removed the tent, a subtle cultural shift.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 100 | bei Position 1242-1243 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 10. November 2021 23:48:47

Even a modest checklist had the effect of distributing power.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 101 | bei Position 1260-1268 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 10. November 2021 23:53:44

Surgery has, essentially, four big killers wherever it is done in the world: infection, bleeding, unsafe anesthesia, and what can only be called the unexpected. For the first three, science and experience have given us some straightforward and valuable preventive measures we think we consistently follow but don’t. These misses are simple failures—perfect for a classic checklist. And as a result, all the researchers’ checklists included precisely specified steps to catch them. But the fourth killer—the unexpected—is an entirely different kind of failure, one that stems from the fundamentally complex risks entailed by opening up a person’s body and trying to tinker with it. Independently, each of the researchers seemed to have realized that no one checklist could anticipate all the pitfalls a team must guard against. So they had determined that the most promising thing to do was just to have people stop and talk through the case together—to be ready as a team to identify and address each patient’s unique, potentially critical dangers.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 107 | bei Position 1339-1340 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:03:22

Their insistence that people talk to one another about each case, at least just for a minute before starting, was basically a strategy to foster teamwork—a kind of team huddle, as it were.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 107 | bei Position 1340-1341 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:03:36

So was another step that these checklists employed, one that was quite unusual in my experience: surgical staff members were expected to stop and make sure that everyone knew one another’s names.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 107 | bei Position 1342-1342 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:04:24

Before starting an operation with a new team,
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 107 | bei Position 1342-1343 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:04:30

Before starting an operation with a new team, there was a check to ensure everyone introduced themselves by name and role:
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 108 | bei Position 1345-1346 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:04:51

There have been psychology studies in various fields backing up what should have been self-evident—people who don’t know one another’s names don’t work together nearly as well as those who do.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 108 | bei Position 1351-1354 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:05:47

when nurses were given a chance to say their names and mention concerns at the beginning of a case, they were more likely to note problems and offer solutions. The researchers called it an “activation phenomenon.” Giving people a chance to say something at the start seemed to activate their sense of participation and responsibility and their willingness to speak up.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 111 | bei Position 1388-1389 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:11:08

It had three “pause points,” as they are called in aviation—three points at which the team must stop to run through a set of checks before proceeding.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 114 | bei Position 1413-1414 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 11. November 2021 00:14:03

Some time after that first miserable try, I did what I should have done to begin with. I went to the library and pulled out a few articles on how flight checklists are made.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 114 | bei Position 1415-1416 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:20:30

The problem of time seemed a serious limitation. But aviation had this challenge, too, and somehow pilots’ checklists met it.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 116 | bei Position 1434-1436 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:23:31

As he walked me through it, however, I realized the handbook was comprised not of one checklist but of scores of them. Each one was remarkably brief, usually just a few lines on a page in big, easy-to-read type. And each applied to a different situation. Taken together, they covered a vast range of flight scenarios.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 120 | bei Position 1488-1488 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:29:27

And Boorman stressed how carefully it was designed for a crew to use in an emergency.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 120 | bei Position 1494-1497 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:30:23

Good checklists, on the other hand, are precise. They are efficient, to the point, and easy to use even in the most difficult situations. They do not try to spell out everything—a checklist cannot fly a plane. Instead, they provide reminders of only the most critical and important steps—the ones that even the highly skilled professionals using them could miss. Good checklists are, above all, practical.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 120 | bei Position 1497-1497 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:30:32

The power of checklists is limited,
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 120 | bei Position 1497-1499 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:30:42

They can help experts remember how to manage a complex process or configure a complex machine. They can make priorities clearer and prompt people to function better as a team. By themselves, however, checklists cannot make anyone follow them.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 121 | bei Position 1504-1506 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:31:53

Pilots nonetheless turn to their checklists for two reasons. First, they are trained to do so. They learn from the beginning of flight school that their memory and judgment are unreliable and that lives depend on their recognizing that fact. Second, the checklists have proved their worth—they work.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 122 | bei Position 1525-1529 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:34:44

When you’re making a checklist, Boorman explained, you have a number of key decisions. You must define a clear pause point at which the checklist is supposed to be used (unless the moment is obvious, like when a warning light goes on or an engine fails). You must decide whether you want a DO-CONFIRM checklist or a READ-DO checklist. With a DO-CONFIRM checklist, he said, team members perform their jobs from memory and experience, often separately. But then they stop. They pause to run the checklist and confirm that everything that was supposed to be done was done. With a READ-DO checklist, on the other hand, people carry out the tasks as they check them off—it’s more like a recipe.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 123 | bei Position 1530-1532 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:35:10

The checklist cannot be lengthy. A rule of thumb some use is to keep it to between five and nine items, which is the limit of working memory. Boorman didn’t think one had to be religious on this point.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 123 | bei Position 1533-1534 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:35:26

But after about sixty to ninety seconds at a given pause point, the checklist often becomes a distraction from other things.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 123 | bei Position 1533-1536 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:35:46

But after about sixty to ninety seconds at a given pause point, the checklist often becomes a distraction from other things. People start “shortcutting.” Steps get missed. So you want to keep the list short by focusing on what he called “the killer items”—the steps that are most dangerous to skip and sometimes overlooked nonetheless.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 123 | bei Position 1537-1540 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:36:21

The wording should be simple and exact, Boorman went on, and use the familiar language of the profession. Even the look of the checklist matters. Ideally, it should fit on one page. It should be free of clutter and unnecessary colors. It should use both uppercase and lowercase text for ease of reading. (He went so far as to recommend using a sans serif type like Helvetica.)
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 124 | bei Position 1541-1544 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:37:01

Boorman was adamant about one further point: no matter how careful we might be, no matter how much thought we might put in, a checklist has to be tested in the real world, which is inevitably more complicated than expected. First drafts always fall apart, he said, and one needs to study how, make changes, and keep testing until the checklist works consistently.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 128 | bei Position 1598-1600 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:44:46

It is common to misconceive how checklists function in complex lines of work. They are not comprehensive how-to guides, whether for building a skyscraper or getting a plane out of trouble. They are quick and simple tools aimed to buttress the skills of expert professionals.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 132 | bei Position 1655-1656 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:52:11

first think about what happens in most lines of professional work when a major failure occurs. To begin with, we rarely investigate our failures.
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 133 | bei Position 1657-1658 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 12. November 2021 00:52:27

A single type of error can affect thousands, but because it usually touches only one person at a time, we tend not to search as hard for explanations.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 137 | bei Position 1696-1698 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 01:23:16

In aviation, there is a reason the “pilot not flying” starts the checklist, someone pointed out. The “pilot flying” can be distracted by flight tasks and liable to skip a checklist. Moreover, dispersing the responsibility sends the message that everyone—not just the captain—is responsible for the overall well-being of the flight and should have the power to question the process.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 137 | bei Position 1700-1702 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 01:23:38

Must nurses make written check marks? No, we decided, they didn’t have to. This wasn’t a record-keeping procedure. We were aiming for a team conversation to ensure that everyone had reviewed what was needed for the case to go as well as possible.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 138 | bei Position 1707-1707 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 01:24:16

use. Furthermore, an item critical to one expert might not be critical to another.

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 138 | bei Position 1706-1707 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 01:24:20

An inherent tension exists between brevity and effectiveness. Cut too much and you won’t have enough checks to improve care. Leave too much in and the list becomes too long to use. Furthermore, an item critical to one expert might not be critical to another.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 158 | bei Position 1958-1959 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:09:13

We have an opportunity before us, not just in medicine but in virtually any endeavor. Even the most expert among us can gain from searching out the patterns of mistakes and failures and putting a few checks in place.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 160 | bei Position 1980-1987 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:12:52

Now, if surgeons end up using the checklist anyway, what is the big deal if we do so without joy in our souls? We’re doing it. That’s what matters, right? Not necessarily. Just ticking boxes is not the ultimate goal here. Embracing a culture of teamwork and discipline is. And if we recognize the opportunity, the two-minute WHO checklist is just a start. It is a single, broad-brush device intended to catch a few problems common to all operations, and we surgeons could build on it to do even more. We could adopt, for example, specialized checklists for hip replacement procedures, pancreatic operations, aortic aneurysm repairs, examining each of our major procedures for their most common avoidable glitches and incorporating checks to help us steer clear of them. We could even devise emergency checklists, like aviation has, for nonroutine situations—such as the cardiac arrest my friend John described in which the doctors forgot that an overdose of potassium could be a cause.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 160 | bei Position 1987-1993 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:13:43

Beyond the operating room, moreover, there are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of things doctors do that are as dangerous and prone to error as surgery. Take, for instance, the treatment of heart attacks, strokes, drug overdoses, pneumonias, kidney failures, seizures. And consider the many other situations that are only seemingly simpler and less dire—the evaluation of a patient with a headache, for example, a funny chest pain, a lung nodule, a breast lump. All involve risk, uncertainty, and complexity—and therefore steps that are worth committing to a checklist and testing in routine care. Good checklists could become as important for doctors and nurses as good stethoscopes (which, unlike checklists, have never been proved to make a difference in patient care). The hard question—still unanswered—is whether medical culture can seize the opportunity.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 163 | bei Position 2019-2020 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:17:23

Neuroscientists have found that the prospect of making money stimulates the same primitive reward circuits in the brain that cocaine does.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 163 | bei Position 2020-2024 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:17:49

And that, Pabrai said, is when serious investors like himself try to become systematic. They focus on dispassionate analysis, on avoiding both irrational exuberance and panic. They pore over the company’s financial reports, investigate its liabilities and risks, examine its management team’s track record, weigh its competitors, consider the future of the market it is in—trying to gauge both the magnitude of opportunity and the margin of safety.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 165 | bei Position 2044-2046 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:20:56

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 166 | bei Position 2062-2066 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:23:31

he was even more methodical: he enumerated the errors known to occur at any point in the investment process—during the research phase, during decision making, during execution of the decision, and even in the period after making an investment when one should be monitoring for problems. He then designed detailed checklists to avoid the errors, complete with clearly identified pause points at which he and his investment team would run through the items.

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 165 | bei Position 2048-2049 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:23:55

==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 167 | bei Position 2078-2081 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 13. November 2021 22:26:14

there’s nothing to be found. “But then there is.” The checklist doesn’t tell him what to do, he explained. It is not a formula. But the checklist helps him be as smart as possible every step of the way, ensuring that he’s got the critical information he needs when he needs it, that he’s systematic about decision making, that he’s talked to everyone he should.

The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 173 | bei Position 2147-2151 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:37:05

We don’t like checklists. They can be painstaking. They’re not much fun. But I don’t think the issue here is mere laziness. There’s something deeper, more visceral going on when people walk away not only from saving lives but from making money. It somehow feels beneath us to use a checklist, an embarrassment. It runs counter to deeply held beliefs about how the truly great among us—those we aspire to be—handle situations of high stakes and complexity. The truly great are daring. They improvise. They do not have protocols
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 177 | bei Position 2201-2203 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:45:35

The fear people have about the idea of adherence to protocol is rigidity. They imagine mindless automatons, heads down in a checklist, incapable of looking out their windshield and coping with the real world in front of them. But what you find, when a checklist is well made, is exactly the opposite. The checklist gets the dumb stuff out of the way, the routines your brain shouldn’t have to occupy itself with
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 182 | bei Position 2266-2270 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:55:05

The crew of US Airways Flight 1549 showed an ability to adhere to vital procedures when it mattered most, to remain calm under pressure, to recognize where one needed to improvise and where one needed not to improvise. They understood how to function in a complex and dire situation. They recognized that it required teamwork and preparation and that it required them long before the situation became complex and dire. This was what was unusual. This is what it means to be a hero in the modern era. These are the rare qualities that we must understand are needed in the larger world.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 182 | bei Position 2272-2276 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:56:05

First is an expectation of selflessness: that we who accept responsibility for others—whether we are doctors, lawyers, teachers, public authorities, soldiers, or pilots—will place the needs and concerns of those who depend on us above our own. Second is an expectation of skill: that we will aim for excellence in our knowledge and expertise. Third is an expectation of trustworthiness: that we will be responsible in our personal behavior toward our charges.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 182 | bei Position 2272-2277 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:56:24

First is an expectation of selflessness: that we who accept responsibility for others—whether we are doctors, lawyers, teachers, public authorities, soldiers, or pilots—will place the needs and concerns of those who depend on us above our own. Second is an expectation of skill: that we will aim for excellence in our knowledge and expertise. Third is an expectation of trustworthiness: that we will be responsible in our personal behavior toward our charges. Aviators, however, add a fourth expectation, discipline: discipline in following prudent procedure and in functioning with others.
==========
The Checklist Manifesto (Gawande, Atul)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 183 | bei Position 2281-2284 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 14. November 2021 22:58:34

discipline. Discipline is hard—harder than trustworthiness and skill and perhaps even than selflessness. We are by nature flawed and inconstant creatures. We can’t even keep from snacking between meals. We are not built for discipline. We are built for novelty and excitement, not for careful attention to detail. Discipline is something we have to work at.

INTRODUCTION You Can Do—and Be—So Much More Than You Think
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 1 | bei Position 85-93 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:21:15

I’d been told success was all about mind-set, and I wanted to lock in the optimal psychological state before the rubber met the road. We can all remember those times when we were hit with a lightning bolt of inspiration, whether to work out or to start learning French—and we can also remember how that urge never produced any action. I was in the grip of an insidious myth. I thought motivation was a prerequisite to starting a tedious learning process—a spark necessary to get me going. But motivation is really a result. Motivation is the fire that starts burning after you manually, painfully, coax it into existence, and it feeds on the satisfaction of seeing yourself make progress. The problem with waiting for motivation to strike is that it almost never comes with enough voltage to actually get you started. Granted, sometimes motivation strikes like a hammer. Minutes or hours later, though, you’ve lost your enthusiasm, partly because a lightning-bolt burst of motivation is like a sugar rush: It feels great but is impossible to maintain, and when you come down you actually feel worse.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 98-98 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:21:48

HOW SUCCESSFUL PEOPLE APPROACH MOTIVATION
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 99-100 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:22:02

I’ve met plenty of successful people. Yes, many of them are smart. Yes, some of them are creative. Yes, they’re often talented. But none of those traits is crucial to their success.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 101-102 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:23:32

Humble beginnings can create the perfect foundation for success, because starting at the bottom creates almost endless opportunities to enjoy small successes.
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 103-103 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:23:36

There is only one recipe for gaining motivation: success.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 103-104 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:23:40

Specifically, the dopamine hits we get when we observe ourselves making progress.

The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 105-106 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:23:56

If you want to stay motivated, if you want to stay on track, if you want to keep making progress toward the things you hope to achieve, the key is to enjoy small, seemingly minor successes—but on a regular basis.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 108-111 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:24:20

Small successes are fun—and motivating. That’s why you already have everything you need. That’s why motivation isn’t something you have. Motivation is something you get, from yourself, automatically, from feeling good about achieving small successes.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 4 | bei Position 111-113 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:24:45

Success is a process. Success is repeatable and predictable. Success has less to do with hoping and praying and strategizing than with diligently doing (after a little strategizing, sure): doing the right things, the right way, over and over and over.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 4 | bei Position 118-120 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:25:32

When you consistently do the right things, success is predictable. Success is inevitable. You just can’t think about it too much. No obsessing allowed.
==========

THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HAPPINESS AND SUCCESS
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 121-124 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:26:09

motivation myth makes us unhappy for two reasons. First, it leads to a sin of commission. A person who self-identifies as a failure, who regularly quits before reaching the finish line, is a chronically unhappy person. But it also causes a sin of omission. We aren’t mindfully enjoying one of the most rewarding experiences on earth: slowly growing stronger, or more skillful, or more wise.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 5 | bei Position 121-124 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:26:15

The motivation myth makes us unhappy for two reasons. First, it leads to a sin of commission. A person who self-identifies as a failure, who regularly quits before reaching the finish line, is a chronically unhappy person. But it also causes a sin of omission. We aren’t mindfully enjoying one of the most rewarding experiences on earth: slowly growing stronger, or more skillful, or more wise.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 7 | bei Position 145-147 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:27:11

At the end of my grandfather’s racing journey, he was left with what we are all left with, no matter what we have accomplished and no matter how much praise or recognition we have received from others. The accomplishment, no matter how amazing, is just the cherry on top of the fulfillment cake.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 7 | bei Position 150-152 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:27:16

The road to a target, to a goal, or to a finish line is filled with countless hours of work and determination and sacrifice . . . and countless opportunities to feel good about what you have accomplished, each and every day along the way.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 7 | bei Position 152-153 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:27:27

A slice of satisfaction, fulfillment, and happiness can be found in the achievement . . . but the real source of consistent, lasting happiness lies in the process.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 8 | bei Position 157-159 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:27:53

That’s why to-do lists are so popular. (Many people write down really easy tasks—or tasks they’ve already completed—just so they can scratch them off.)

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 8 | bei Position 159-160 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:28:00

Incredibly successful people set a goal and then focus all their attention on the process necessary to achieve that goal. They set a goal and then, surprisingly, they forget the goal.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 8 | bei Position 160-162 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:28:10

Sure, the goal is still out there. But what they care about most is what they need to do today—and when they accomplish that, they are happy about today. They feel good about today.
==========
The Motivation Myth (Haden, Jeff)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 8 | bei Position 162-164 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 29. November 2021 23:28:29

that sense of accomplishment gives them all the motivation they need to do what they need to do when tomorrow comes—because success, even tiny, incremental success, is the best motivational tool of all.
