dopamine is the biological basis of exploration and innovation.

==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)

Of course, the opposite is also true: when progress is missing, the cost is steep. The sensation of being stuck in the mud, wheels spinning and not getting anywhere, is the single largest drain on motivation that scientists have discovered.

The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 49 | bei Position 687-688 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:32:36

FLOW TRIGGERS
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 49 | bei Position 693-695 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:33:33

To date, researchers have identified twenty-two different flow triggers—there are probably more—yet they all share one thing in common. Flow follows focus. The state can only arise when all of our attention is directed at the present moment.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 49 | bei Position 693-696 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:33:38

To date, researchers have identified twenty-two different flow triggers—there are probably more—yet they all share one thing in common. Flow follows focus. The state can only arise when all of our attention is directed at the present moment. So that’s exactly what all these triggers do: they drive attention into the now.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 49 | bei Position 697-700 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:34:03

Either they push dopamine and/or norepinephrine, two of the brain’s main focusing chemicals, into our system, or they lower cognitive load, which is the psychological weight of all the stuff we’re thinking about at any one time. By lowering cognitive load, we’re liberating energy, which the brain can then repurpose for paying attention to the task at hand.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 700-702 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:34:25

This is where curiosity, passion, purpose, autonomy, and mastery come back into this story. Our five most powerful intrinsic drivers do double duty as flow triggers. All of these motivators can drive dopamine into our system. Many of them do the same for norepinephrine. And when all five are properly aligned, they lower cognitive load as well.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 709-712 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:35:42

While curiosity, passion, purpose, and autonomy alter our neurobiology automatically, both increasing drive and—as a result of the changes in neurochemistry that produce that increase in drive—increasing our chance of getting into flow, mastery requires some additional fine-tuning.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 712-714 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:36:06

As a flow trigger, mastery is referred to as the “challenge-skills balance.”20 The idea is relatively straightforward: Flow follows focus, and we pay the most attention to the task at hand, when the challenge of that task slightly exceeds our skill set.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 731-733 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:38:33

To really harness mastery as a motivator, take the 15 percent of your life that you’ve carved out for yourself—call it your autonomy time—and spend it pushing on that challenge-skills balance, trying to get a little better at something that’s aligned with curiosity, passion, and purpose.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 734-735 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:38:47

Try to get a little better today, try to get a little better tomorrow. And repeat. And repeat.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 55 | bei Position 748-749 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 3. September 2022 23:40:11

Goals GOAL SETTING 101
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 757-758 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:47:08

Simple as the idea of goal setting might seem, there’s trouble in the particulars.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 758-759 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:47:28

What the research shows is that not every goal is the same, nor is every goal appropriate for every situation and—most important—the wrong goal in the wrong situation can seriously hinder performance and actually lower productivity and motivation.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 762-763 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:47:54

the establishment of a goal is one of the easiest ways to increase motivation and enhance performance.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 773-774 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:49:22

setting goals increased performance and productivity 11 to 25 percent.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 780-783 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:50:32

The brain is a prediction engine.6 It’s always trying to predict what is about to happen next and how much energy will be required by that situation. To make those predictions, three systems come into play: information acquisition, pattern recognition, and goal direction. We take in information, find connections between this information and prior experience, and then filter those results through our goals to decide what to do next.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 780-785 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:50:53

The brain is a prediction engine.6 It’s always trying to predict what is about to happen next and how much energy will be required by that situation. To make those predictions, three systems come into play: information acquisition, pattern recognition, and goal direction. We take in information, find connections between this information and prior experience, and then filter those results through our goals to decide what to do next. And since that decision is an action and actions require energy—how much energy exactly?—that is precisely what the brain is always trying to predict.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 785-787 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:51:17

Give the goal direction system a goal and you give the pattern recognition system a purpose and the information acquisition system a target. And why does this target matter so much? Because consciousness is an extremely limited resource.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 796-797 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:52:41

Because the brain is a prediction engine and consciousness is a limited resource, fear and goals are the basic building blocks of our reality.
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 798-800 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:53:01

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 60 | bei Position 831-834 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:58:16

By giving voice to an aim, you’re creating what’s called a “social reality,” and this has negative consequences for real reality. The act of telling someone about your goal gives you the feeling that the goal’s already been achieved. It releases the dopamine you’re supposed to get afterward, prematurely.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 61 | bei Position 840-842 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 4. September 2022 23:59:48

Turns out, there are significant differences between high, hard goals and clear goals, which are all the daily sub-steps required to accomplish those high, hard goals. It comes down to timescale.
==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 61 | bei Position 843-844 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:00:23

Clear goals are the inverse. They’re all the tiny, daily steps it takes to accomplish that mission.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 849-849 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:01:26

So what does this look like in the real world? Daily “to-do” lists.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 849-850 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:01:35

So what does this look like in the real world? Daily “to-do” lists. A proper to-do list is just a set of clear goals for your day.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 851-852 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:02:06

Each item on that list originated with your massively transformative purpose, was chunked down into a high, hard goal, then further reduced to what you can do today to advance that cause.

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 855-856 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:04:11

Equally crucial, clear goals are an important flow trigger.12 The state requires focus, and clear goals tell us where and when to put our attention.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 858-859 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:05:16

clear goals act as a priority list for the brain, lowering cognitive load and telling the system where to expend its energy. Applying this idea in our daily life means breaking tasks into bite-sized chunks and setting goals accordingly.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 863-864 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:06:01

Taken together, what all this means is that proper goal setting requires three sets of goals: massively transformative, high and hard, and clear—for three different timescales.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 863-864 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:06:07

Taken together, what all this means is that proper goal setting requires three sets of goals: massively transformative, high and hard, and clear—for three different timescales. MTPs last a lifetime; high, hard goals can take years; clear goals are accomplished one minute at a time.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 863-867 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:06:27

Taken together, what all this means is that proper goal setting requires three sets of goals: massively transformative, high and hard, and clear—for three different timescales. MTPs last a lifetime; high, hard goals can take years; clear goals are accomplished one minute at a time. But it also means knowing which goal to focus on when. Across the shorter timescales of the moment, attention needs to be on the task at hand (the clear goal) and not the reason for doing the task (the high, hard goal or MTP). Getting this wrong can block flow—depriving goal setters of the very boost in performance they’ll need to achieve those goals.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 860-867 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:07:16

out again. A proper clear goal sits right inside your challenge-skill sweet spot, meaning it’s hard enough to stretch you to the edge of your abilities, but not hard enough to push you beyond, into that demotivating realm of anxiety and overwhelm. Taken together, what all this means is that proper goal setting requires three sets of goals: massively transformative, high and hard, and clear—for three different timescales. The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 62 | bei Position 860-868 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:07:31

out again. A proper clear goal sits right inside your challenge-skill sweet spot, meaning it’s hard enough to stretch you to the edge of your abilities, but not hard enough to push you beyond, into that demotivating realm of anxiety and overwhelm. Taken together, what all this means is that proper goal setting requires three sets of goals: massively transformative, high and hard, and clear—for three different timescales. MTPs last a lifetime; high, hard goals can take years; clear goals are accomplished one minute at a time. But it also means knowing which goal to focus on when. Across the shorter timescales of the moment, attention needs to be on the task at hand (the clear goal) and not the reason for doing the task (the high, hard goal or MTP). Getting this wrong can block flow—depriving goal setters of the very boost in performance they’ll need to achieve those goals. When it comes to writing up your daily to-do lists, try to write the next day’s list at the end of the previous day. That way, you can get after it the moment you get to work.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 871-874 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:07:51

Figure out what works best for you. Conduct your own experiment. Track how many things you can do in a day and still be your best at all of them. Do this every day for a few weeks and you’ll light upon the magic number. That’s how many items you should put on your daily list of clear goals. By getting this right, we maximize motivation. But we also know when to declare the day a success.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 874-876 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:08:11

For me, if I tick off all eight items on my daily to-do list, then I’ve “won” my day. It’s done. I can turn off my brain and recover. This is important. Recovery is critical to sustained peak performance, but peak performers can become a little obsessive, getting into workaholic mode and never getting out.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 63 | bei Position 874-877 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:08:20

For me, if I tick off all eight items on my daily to-do list, then I’ve “won” my day. It’s done. I can turn off my brain and recover. This is important. Recovery is critical to sustained peak performance, but peak performers can become a little obsessive, getting into workaholic mode and never getting out. So knowing how to stop working without feeling bad about stopping is key for long-term success.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 879-881 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 5. September 2022 00:08:53

THE GRIT TO PERSEVERE
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 930-931 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:55:08

as Duckworth puts it, “All high achievers are paragons of perseverance.”
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 931-932 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:55:21

Perseverance is the most familiar version of grit. It’s day-to-day steadfastness.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 68 | bei Position 935-940 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:56:20

Psychologists have found that humans can achieve three levels of well-being on this planet, each more pleasurable than the last.9 The first level is moment-to-moment “happiness” or what’s often described as a hedonic approach to life. The next level up is “engagement,” which is defined as a high-flow lifestyle, or one where happiness is achieved not by the pursuit of pleasure but rather through seeking out challenging tasks that have a high likelihood of producing flow. The next level up, the peak level of happiness and the best we get to feel on the planet, is known as “purpose,” which blends the high-flow lifestyle of level two with the desire to impact lives beyond our own.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 69 | bei Position 941-942 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:56:36

clear link between grit and what level of happiness people pursue.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 69 | bei Position 941-943 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:57:10

clear link between grit and what level of happiness people pursue.10 Less gritty people hunt happiness through pleasure, while grittier folks choose engagement. By consistently choosing engagement and triggering flow, the grittier folks are actually getting more happiness, not less.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 69 | bei Position 941-945 | Hinzugefügt am Mittwoch, 7. September 2022 23:57:33

clear link between grit and what level of happiness people pursue.10 Less gritty people hunt happiness through pleasure, while grittier folks choose engagement. By consistently choosing engagement and triggering flow, the grittier folks are actually getting more happiness, not less. Thus, while grit requires more energy and emotional fortitude in the short run, it provides a much bigger boost in mood and motivation in the long run.
==========

MINDSET
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 71 | bei Position 982-983 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 8. September 2022 23:48:51

Either you have a fixed mindset, meaning you believe talent is innate and no amount of practice will ever help you improve, or you have a growth mindset, meaning you believe talent is merely a starting point and practice makes all the difference.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 71 | bei Position 982-985 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 8. September 2022 23:48:59

Either you have a fixed mindset, meaning you believe talent is innate and no amount of practice will ever help you improve, or you have a growth mindset, meaning you believe talent is merely a starting point and practice makes all the difference. And for sustained perseverance, the research shows, a growth mindset is indispensable.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 990-992 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 8. September 2022 23:49:49

Growth mindsetters work harder, longer, and smarter, deploying a much wider range of problem-solving strategies when facing complicated challenges. They also have an easier time getting into and staying in flow.
==========
The Art of Impossible (Kotler, Steven)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 992-994 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 8. September 2022 23:50:30

This uptick in flow comes down to concentration. When fixed mindsetters make an error, they tend to dwell on it. This wrecks their ability to keep their focus in the here and now. Not so for growth mindsetters. “Live and learn,” says the growth mindset—and more flow is the result.
==========

Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 3 | bei Position 244-246 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 14:46:41

calibrated questions: queries that the other side can respond to but that have no fixed answers. It buys you time. It gives your counterpart the illusion of control—they are the one with the answers and power after all—and it does all that without giving them any idea of how constrained they are by it.

THE SMARTEST DUMB GUY IN THE ROOM
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 6 | bei Position 280-281 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 14:52:09

Andy would throw out an offer and give a rationally airtight explanation for why it was a good one—an inescapable logic trap—and I’d answer with some variation of “How am I supposed to do that?”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 7 | bei Position 300-303 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 14:53:49

While I wasn’t actually saying “No,” the questions I kept asking sounded like it. They seemed to insinuate that the other side was being dishonest and unfair. And that was enough to make them falter and negotiate with themselves. Answering my calibrated questions demanded deep emotional strengths and tactical psychological insights that the toolbox they’d been given did not contain.

HEART VS. MIND
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 11 | bei Position 366-366 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:13:50

Feeling, they discovered, is a form of thinking.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 372-373 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:14:45

Kahneman proved that humans all suffer from Cognitive Bias, that is, unconscious—and irrational—brain processes that literally distort the way we see the world.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 374-378 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:15:17

them. There’s the Framing Effect, which demonstrates that people respond differently to the same choice depending on how it is framed (people place greater value on moving from 90 percent to 100 percent—high probability to certainty—than from 45 percent to 55 percent, even though they’re both ten percentage points). Prospect Theory explains why we take unwarranted risks in the face of uncertain losses. And the most famous is Loss Aversion, which shows how people are statistically more likely to act to avert a loss than to achieve an equal gain.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 378-380 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:15:39

Kahneman later codified his research in the 2011 bestseller Thinking, Fast and Slow.3 Man, he wrote, has two systems of thought: System 1, our animal mind, is fast, instinctive, and emotional; System 2 is slow, deliberative, and logical. And System 1 is far more influential.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 378-381 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:15:43

Kahneman later codified his research in the 2011 bestseller Thinking, Fast and Slow.3 Man, he wrote, has two systems of thought: System 1, our animal mind, is fast, instinctive, and emotional; System 2 is slow, deliberative, and logical. And System 1 is far more influential. In fact, it guides and steers our rational thoughts.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 381-383 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:16:10

System 1’s inchoate beliefs, feelings, and impressions are the main sources of the explicit beliefs and deliberate choices of System 2. They’re the spring that feeds the river. We react emotionally (System 1) to a suggestion or question. Then that System 1 reaction informs and in effect creates the System 2 answer.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 12 | bei Position 384-386 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:16:30

if you know how to affect your counterpart’s System 1 thinking, his inarticulate feelings, by how you frame and deliver your questions and statements, then you can guide his System 2 rationality and therefore modify his responses.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 13 | bei Position 390-390 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:16:51

THE FBI GETS EMOTIONAL
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 10 | bei Position 352-360 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:18:58

Two years later, Roger Fisher and William Ury—cofounders of the project—came out with Getting to Yes,2 a groundbreaking treatise on negotiation that totally changed the way practitioners thought about the field. Fisher and Ury’s approach was basically to systematize problem solving so that negotiating parties could reach a mutually beneficial deal—the getting to “Yes” in the title. Their core assumption was that the emotional brain—that animalistic, unreliable, and irrational beast—could be overcome through a more rational, joint problem-solving mindset. Their system was easy to follow and seductive, with four basic tenets. One, separate the person—the emotion—from the problem; two, don’t get wrapped up in the other side’s position (what they’re asking for) but instead focus on their interests (why they’re asking for it) so that you can find what they really want; three, work cooperatively to generate win-win options; and, four, establish mutually agreed-upon standards for evaluating those possible solutions.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 14 | bei Position 399-400 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:19:26

It was becoming glaringly obvious that Getting to Yes didn’t work with kidnappers. No matter how many agents read the book with highlighters in hand, it failed to improve how we as hostage negotiators approached deal making.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 15 | bei Position 415-416 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:20:54

if emotionally driven incidents, not rational bargaining interactions, constituted the bulk of what most police negotiators had to deal with, then
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 15 | bei Position 419-421 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:21:33

What were needed were simple psychological tactics and strategies that worked in the field to calm people down, establish rapport, gain trust, elicit the verbalization of needs, and persuade the other guy of our empathy. We needed something easy to teach, easy to learn, and easy to execute.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 427-429 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:22:23

It all starts with the universally applicable premise that people want to be understood and accepted. Listening is the cheapest, yet most effective concession we can make to get there. By listening intensely, a negotiator demonstrates empathy and shows a sincere desire to better understand what the other side is experiencing.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 429-432 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:22:55

Psychotherapy research shows that when individuals feel listened to, they tend to listen to themselves more carefully and to openly evaluate and clarify their own thoughts and feelings. In addition, they tend to become less defensive and oppositional and more willing to listen to other points of view, which gets them to the calm and logical place where they can be good Getting to Yes problem solvers.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 429-433 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:23:01

Psychotherapy research shows that when individuals feel listened to, they tend to listen to themselves more carefully and to openly evaluate and clarify their own thoughts and feelings. In addition, they tend to become less defensive and oppositional and more willing to listen to other points of view, which gets them to the calm and logical place where they can be good Getting to Yes problem solvers. The whole concept, which you’ll learn as the centerpiece of this book, is called Tactical Empathy.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 429-435 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:23:14

Psychotherapy research shows that when individuals feel listened to, they tend to listen to themselves more carefully and to openly evaluate and clarify their own thoughts and feelings. In addition, they tend to become less defensive and oppositional and more willing to listen to other points of view, which gets them to the calm and logical place where they can be good Getting to Yes problem solvers. The whole concept, which you’ll learn as the centerpiece of this book, is called Tactical Empathy. This is listening as a martial art, balancing the subtle behaviors of emotional intelligence and the assertive skills of influence, to gain access to the mind of another person. Contrary to popular opinion, listening is not a passive activity. It is the most active thing you can do.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 16 | bei Position 438-439 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:28:23

CHAPTER 2 BE A MIRROR

ASSUMPTIONS BLIND, HYPOTHESES GUIDE
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 547-548 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:55:46

Good negotiators, going in, know they have to be ready for possible surprises; great negotiators aim to use their skills to reveal the surprises they are certain exist.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 24 | bei Position 547-550 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:56:06

Good negotiators, going in, know they have to be ready for possible surprises; great negotiators aim to use their skills to reveal the surprises they are certain exist. Experience will have taught them that they are best served by holding multiple hypotheses—about the situation, about the counterpart’s wants, about a whole array of variables—in their mind at the same time. Present and alert in the moment, they use all the new information
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 553-555 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:56:32

Your goal at the outset is to extract and observe as much information as possible. Which, by the way, is one of the reasons that really smart people often have trouble being negotiators—they’re so smart they think they don’t have anything to discover.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 557-558 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:58:12

Great negotiators are able to question the assumptions that the rest of the involved players accept on faith or in arrogance, and thus remain more
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 557-559 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:58:16

Great negotiators are able to question the assumptions that the rest of the involved players accept on faith or in arrogance, and thus remain more emotionally open to all possibilities, and more intellectually agile to a fluid situation.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 25 | bei Position 562-564 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 15:59:19

I hadn’t yet learned to be aware of a counterpart’s overuse of personal pronouns—we/they or me/I. The less important he makes himself, the more important he probably is (and vice versa).

CALM THE SCHIZOPHRENIC
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 582-583 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:02:11

You want to put some distance between you and whatever worst-case scenario might be waiting at the other end of the deal.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 590-592 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:03:21

It’s really not that easy to listen well. We are easily distracted. We engage in selective listening, hearing only what we want to hear, our minds acting on a cognitive bias for consistency rather than truth.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 27 | bei Position 592-596 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:03:43

Most people approach a negotiation so preoccupied by the arguments that support their position that they are unable to listen attentively. In one of the most cited research papers in psychology,1 George A. Miller persuasively put forth the idea that we can process only about seven pieces of information in our conscious mind at any given moment. In other words, we are easily overwhelmed.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 596-597 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:04:00

For those people who view negotiation as a battle of arguments, it’s the voices in their own head that are overwhelming them. When they’re not talking, they’re thinking
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 596-597 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:04:11

For those people who view negotiation as a battle of arguments, it’s the voices in their own head that are overwhelming them.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 596-599 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:04:35

For those people who view negotiation as a battle of arguments, it’s the voices in their own head that are overwhelming them. When they’re not talking, they’re thinking about their arguments, and when they are talking, they’re making their arguments. Often those on both sides of the table are doing the same thing, so you have what I call a state of schizophrenia: everyone just listening to the voice in their head
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 602-605 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:05:24

Instead of prioritizing your argument—in fact, instead of doing any thinking at all in the early goings about what you’re going to say—make your sole and all-encompassing focus the other person and what they have to say. In that mode of true active listening—aided by the tactics you’ll learn in the following chapters—you’ll disarm your counterpart. You’ll make them feel safe. The voice in their head will begin to quiet down.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 602-606 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:05:33

Instead of prioritizing your argument—in fact, instead of doing any thinking at all in the early goings about what you’re going to say—make your sole and all-encompassing focus the other person and what they have to say. In that mode of true active listening—aided by the tactics you’ll learn in the following chapters—you’ll disarm your counterpart. You’ll make them feel safe. The voice in their head will begin to quiet down. The goal is to identify what your counterparts actually need (monetarily, emotionally, or otherwise) and get them feeling safe enough to talk and talk and talk some more about what they want.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 28 | bei Position 606-610 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:06:42

Wants are easy to talk about, representing the aspiration of getting our way, and sustaining any illusion of control we have as we begin to negotiate; needs imply survival, the very minimum required to make us act, and so make us vulnerable. But neither wants nor needs are where we start; it begins with listening, making it about the other people, validating their emotions, and creating enough trust and safety for a real conversation to begin.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 29 | bei Position 621-622 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:08:19

SLOW. IT. DOWN.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 631-632 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:09:52

Going too fast is one of the mistakes all negotiators are prone to making. If we’re too much in a hurry, people can feel as if they’re not being heard and we risk undermining the rapport and trust we’ve built.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 631-634 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:10:09

Going too fast is one of the mistakes all negotiators are prone to making. If we’re too much in a hurry, people can feel as if they’re not being heard and we risk undermining the rapport and trust we’ve built. There’s plenty of research that now validates the passage of time as one of the most important tools for a negotiator. When you slow the process down, you also calm it down. After all, if someone is talking, they’re not shooting.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 30 | bei Position 630-633 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:10:15

trying to be a problem solver, not a people mover. Going too fast is one of the mistakes all negotiators are prone to making. If we’re too much in a hurry, people can feel as if they’re not being heard and we risk undermining the rapport and trust we’ve built. There’s plenty of research that now validates the passage of time as one of the most important tools for a negotiator. When you slow the process down, you also calm it down.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 31 | bei Position 647-648 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:11:59

THE VOICE
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 31 | bei Position 650-651 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:17:47

Late-Night, FM DJ Voice: deep, soft, slow, and reassuring.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 656-657 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:18:46

The best way to describe the late-night FM DJ’s voice is as the voice of calm and reason.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 657-659 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:19:28

When deliberating on a negotiating strategy or approach, people tend to focus all their energies on what to say or do, but it’s how we are (our general demeanor and delivery) that is both the easiest thing to enact and the most immediately effective mode of influence.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 657-661 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 29. Oktober 2022 16:19:53

When deliberating on a negotiating strategy or approach, people tend to focus all their energies on what to say or do, but it’s how we are (our general demeanor and delivery) that is both the easiest thing to enact and the most immediately effective mode of influence. Our brains don’t just process and understand the actions and words of others but their feelings and intentions too, the social meaning of their behavior and their emotions. On a mostly unconscious level, we can understand the minds of others not through any kind of thinking but through quite literally grasping what the other is feeling.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 665-666 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:42:01

your most powerful tool in any verbal communication is your voice.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 666-667 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:42:13

You can use your voice to intentionally reach into someone’s brain and flip an emotional switch.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 33 | bei Position 671-674 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:43:04

Most of the time, you should be using the positive/playful voice. It’s the voice of an easygoing, good-natured person. Your attitude is light and encouraging. The key here is to relax and smile while you’re talking. A smile, even while talking on the phone, has an impact tonally that the other person will pick up on.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 668-670 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:43:13

There are essentially three voice tones available to negotiators: the late-night FM DJ voice, the positive/playful voice, and the direct or assertive voice. Forget the assertive voice for now; except in very rare circumstances, using it is like slapping yourself in the face while you’re trying to make progress.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 32 | bei Position 668-671 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:43:17

There are essentially three voice tones available to negotiators: the late-night FM DJ voice, the positive/playful voice, and the direct or assertive voice. Forget the assertive voice for now; except in very rare circumstances, using it is like slapping yourself in the face while you’re trying to make progress. You’re signaling dominance onto your counterpart, who will either aggressively, or passive-aggressively, push back against attempts to be controlled.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 33 | bei Position 680-682 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:44:21

When people are in a positive frame of mind, they think more quickly, and are more likely to collaborate and problem-solve (instead of fight and resist). It applies to the smile-er as much as to the smile-ee: a smile on your face, and in your voice, will increase your own mental agility.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 33 | bei Position 682-683 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:44:48

The way the late-night FM DJ voice works is that, when you inflect your voice in a downward way, you put it out there that you’ve got it covered.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 33 | bei Position 682-684 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:44:52

The way the late-night FM DJ voice works is that, when you inflect your voice in a downward way, you put it out there that you’ve got it covered. Talking slowly and clearly you convey one idea: I’m in control.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 34 | bei Position 690-691 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:45:53

You can be very direct and to the point as long as you create safety by a tone of voice that says I’m okay, you’re okay, let’s figure things out.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 35 | bei Position 701-702 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:46:55

MIRRORING
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 35 | bei Position 710-711 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:48:21

Mirroring, also called isopraxism, is essentially imitation. It’s another neurobehavior humans (and other animals) display in which we copy each other to comfort each other.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 35 | bei Position 711-712 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:48:28

It can be done with speech patterns, body language, vocabulary, tempo, and tone of voice.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 35 | bei Position 712-714 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:48:39

It’s generally an unconscious behavior—we are rarely aware of it when it’s happening—but it’s a sign that people are bonding, in sync, and establishing the kind of rapport that leads to trust.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 36 | bei Position 721-722 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 30. Oktober 2022 23:50:16

It’s almost laughably simple: for the FBI, a “mirror” is when you repeat the last three words (or the critical one to three words) of what someone has just said.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 43 | bei Position 833-834 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 00:04:39

being right isn’t the key to a successful negotiation—having the right mindset is.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 834-835 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 00:04:44

HOW TO CONFRONT—AND GET YOUR WAY—WITHOUT CONFRONTATION
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 835-836 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:01:42

I only half-jokingly refer to mirroring as magic or a Jedi mind trick because it gives you the ability to disagree without being disagreeable.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 44 | bei Position 841-848 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:01:49

It’s just four simple steps: 1.​Use the late-night FM DJ voice. 2.​Start with “I’m sorry . . .” 3.​Mirror. 4.​Silence. At least four seconds, to let the mirror work its magic on your counterpart. 5.​Repeat.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 45 | bei Position 855-855 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:02:44

deliver the mirror in an inquisitive tone.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 45 | bei Position 855-856 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:02:57

deliver the mirror in an inquisitive tone. The intention behind most mirrors should be “Please, help me understand.”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 45 | bei Position 855-859 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:03:40

deliver the mirror in an inquisitive tone. The intention behind most mirrors should be “Please, help me understand.” Every time you mirror someone, they will reword what they’ve said. They will never say it exactly the same way they said it the first time. Ask someone, “What do you mean by that?” and you’re likely to incite irritation or defensiveness. A mirror, however, will get you the clarity you want while signaling respect and concern for what the other person is saying.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 45 | bei Position 864-865 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:06:25

When another person’s tone of voice or body language is inconsistent with his words, a good mirror can be particularly useful.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 870-871 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:07:20

Mirroring will make you feel awkward as heck when you first try it. That’s the only hard part about it; the technique takes a little practice.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 46 | bei Position 872-873 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:07:27

CHAPTER 3 DON’T FEEL THEIR PAIN, LABEL IT
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 48 | bei Position 917-919 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:16:11

Emotions are one of the main things that derail communication. Once people get upset at one another, rational thinking goes out the window.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 919-919 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:16:17

instead of denying or ignoring emotions, good negotiators identify and influence them.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 50 | bei Position 919-920 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:16:30

instead of denying or ignoring emotions, good negotiators identify and influence them. They are able to precisely label emotions, those of others and especially their own. And once they label the emotions they talk about them without getting wound up.
==========

empathy is “the ability to recognize the perspective of a counterpart, and the vocalization of that recognition.”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 948-948 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:19:39

empathy is paying attention to another human being, asking
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 951-951 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:19:55

One step beyond that is tactical empathy.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 52 | bei Position 951-953 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:20:18

Tactical empathy is understanding the feelings and mindset of another in the moment and also hearing what is behind those feelings so you increase your influence in all the moments that follow.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 53 | bei Position 964-965 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:26:18

When we closely observe a person’s face, gestures, and tone of voice, our brain begins to align with theirs in a process called neural resonance, and that lets us know more fully what they think and feel.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 53 | bei Position 969-971 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:27:10

If you want to increase your neural resonance skills, take a moment right now and practice. Turn your attention to someone who’s talking near you, or watch a person being interviewed on TV. As they talk, imagine that you are that person. Visualize yourself in the position they describe and put in as much detail as you can, as if you were actually there.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)

LABELING
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 989-991 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:29:16

We spotted their feelings, turned them into words, and then very calmly and respectfully repeated their emotions back to them.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 54 | bei Position 991-993 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:29:44

Labeling is a way of validating someone’s emotion by acknowledging it. Give someone’s emotion a name and you show you identify with how that person feels.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 55 | bei Position 993-994 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:29:48

==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 55 | bei Position 995-996 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:30:02

==========

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 55 | bei Position 1000-1001 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:30:47

it has very specific rules about form and delivery.

Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1015-1016 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:33:18

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1016-1017 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:33:31

==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1016-1018 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:33:38

labels almost always begin with roughly the same words: It seems like . . . It sounds like . . . It looks like . . .
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1018-1021 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:34:05

the word “I” gets people’s guard up. When you say “I,” it says you’re more interested in yourself than the other person, and it makes you take personal responsibility for the words that follow—and the offense they might cause. But when you phrase a label as a neutral statement of understanding, it encourages your counterpart to be responsive.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1021-1023 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:34:21

if they disagree with the label, that’s okay. You can always step back and say, “I didn’t say that was what it was. I just said it seems like that.”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 56 | bei Position 1023-1024 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:34:29

The last rule of labeling is silence. Once you’ve thrown out a label, be quiet and listen.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1025-1026 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:34:51

But a label’s power is that it invites the other person to reveal himself.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1028-1029 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:35:08

NEUTRALIZE THE NEGATIVE, REINFORCE THE POSITIVE
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1032-1033 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:37:17

In basic terms, people’s emotions have two levels: the “presenting” behavior is the part above the surface you can see and hear; beneath, the “underlying” feeling is what motivates the
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1032-1033 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:37:21

In basic terms, people’s emotions have two levels: the “presenting” behavior is the part above the surface you can see and hear; beneath, the “underlying” feeling is what motivates the behavior.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1035-1036 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 15:38:01

What good negotiators do when labeling is address those underlying emotions. Labeling negatives diffuses them (or defuses them, in extreme cases); labeling positives reinforces them.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1037-1038 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:35:52

anger is rarely productive—in you or the person you’re negotiating with.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 57 | bei Position 1038-1040 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:36:05

disrupt your ability to properly evaluate and respond to situations. And it blinds you to the fact that you’re angry in the first place, which gives you a false sense of confidence.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 58 | bei Position 1041-1042 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:36:23

Labeling is a helpful tactic in de-escalating angry confrontations, because it makes the person acknowledge their feelings rather than continuing to act out.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1054-1055 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:41:17

Try this the next time you have to apologize for a bone-headed mistake. Go right at it. The fastest and most efficient means of establishing a quick working relationship is to acknowledge the negative and diffuse it.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1057-1058 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:41:44

I’ve found the phrase “Look, I’m an asshole” to be an amazingly effective way to make problems go away.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1064-1065 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:42:47

you can pause briefly, letting him recognize and appreciate your attempts to understand what he’s feeling, and then turn the situation around by offering a positive solution.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 59 | bei Position 1066-1069 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:43:11

Research shows that the best way to deal with negativity is to observe it, without reaction and without judgment. Then consciously label each negative feeling and replace it with positive, compassionate, and solution-based thoughts.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 61 | bei Position 1092-1093 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:48:37

CLEAR THE ROAD BEFORE ADVERTISING THE DESTINATION
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 61 | bei Position 1095-1096 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:52:00

We do that by labeling the fears. These labels are so powerful because they bathe the fears in sunlight, bleaching them of their power and showing our counterpart that we understand.

DO AN ACCUSATION AUDIT
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1134-1137 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:57:57

I don’t ask. Instead, I say, “In case you’re worried about volunteering to role-play with me in front of the class, I want to tell you in advance . . . it’s going to be horrible.” After the laughter dies down, I then say, “And those of you who do volunteer will probably get more out of this than anyone else.” I always end up with more volunteers than I need.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 64 | bei Position 1142-1143 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:58:43

The small but critical mistake this commits is denying the negative. That actually gives it credence.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 65 | bei Position 1146-1147 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 18:59:20

The first step of doing so is listing every terrible thing your counterpart could say about you, in what I call an accusation audit.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)

KEY LESSONS
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1251-1252 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:17:33

These tools, then, are nothing less than emotional best practices that help you cure the pervasive ineptitude that marks our most critical conversations in life.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 71 | bei Position 1249-1252 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:17:41

Whether you are negotiating a business deal or simply chatting to the person at the supermarket butcher counter, creating an empathetic relationship and encouraging your counterpart to expand on their situation is the basis of healthy human interaction. These tools, then, are nothing less than emotional best practices that help you cure the pervasive ineptitude that marks our most critical conversations in life.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1253-1254 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:17:57

With that in mind, I encourage you to take the risk of sprinkling these in every conversation you have.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 72 | bei Position 1253-1255 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:18:04

With that in mind, I encourage you to take the risk of sprinkling these in every conversation you have. I promise you that they will feel awkward and artificial at first, but keep at it. Learning to walk felt awfully strange, too.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 73 | bei Position 1274-1275 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:20:11

CHAPTER 4 BEWARE “YES”—MASTER “NO
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 75 | bei Position 1290-1293 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:21:57

But at the end of the day, “Yes” is often a meaningless answer that hides deeper objections (and “Maybe” is even worse). Pushing hard for “Yes” doesn’t get a negotiator any closer to a win; it just angers the other side. So if “Yes” can be so damn uncomfortable, and “No” such a relief, why have we fetishized one and demonized the other?
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 75 | bei Position 1293-1295 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:22:15

For good negotiators, “No” is pure gold. That negative provides a great opportunity for you and the other party to clarify what you really want by eliminating what you don’t want. “No” is a safe choice that maintains the status quo; it provides a temporary oasis of control.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 75 | bei Position 1298-1299 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 19:22:42

“NO” STARTS THE NEGOTIATION
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 77 | bei Position 1325-1326 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:28:34

A trap into which many fall is to take what other people say literally. I started to see that while people played the game of conversation, it was in the game beneath the game, where few played, that all the leverage lived.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 78 | bei Position 1335-1338 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:30:04

“No” is the start of the negotiation, not the end of it. We’ve been conditioned to fear the word “No.” But it is a statement of perception far more often than of fact. It seldom means, “I have considered all the facts and made a rational choice.” Instead, “No” is often a decision, frequently temporary, to maintain the status quo. Change is scary, and “No” provides a little protection from that scariness.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 78 | bei Position 1340-1342 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:31:58

people will fight to the death to preserve their right to say “No,” so give them that right and the negotiating environment becomes more constructive and collaborative almost immediately.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 78 | bei Position 1339-1342 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:32:17

give their adversary (his word for counterpart) permission to say “No” from the outset of a negotiation. He calls it “the right to veto.” He observes that people will fight to the death to preserve their right to say “No,” so give them that right and the negotiating environment becomes more constructive and collaborative almost immediately.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 1351-1352 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:32:41

your invitation for the other side to say “No”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 1351-1353 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:32:45

your invitation for the other side to say “No” has an amazing power to bring down barriers and allow for beneficial communication.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 1353-1362 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:33:10

When someone tells you “No,” you need to rethink the word in one of its alternative—and much more real—meanings: ■​I am not yet ready to agree; ■​You are making me feel uncomfortable; ■​I do not understand; ■​I don’t think I can afford it; ■​I want something else; ■​I need more information; or ■​I want to talk it over with someone else.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 79 | bei Position 1362-1366 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:33:38

after pausing, ask solution-based questions or simply label their effect: “What about this doesn’t work for you?” “What would you need to make it work?” “It seems like there’s something here that bothers you.” People have a need to say, “No.” So don’t just hope to hear it at some point; get them to say it early.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 80 | bei Position 1366-1366 | Hinzugefügt am Montag, 31. Oktober 2022 23:33:43

PERSUADE IN THEIR WORLD
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 80 | bei Position 1376-1377 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:48:49

There are actually three kinds of “Yes”: Counterfeit, Confirmation, and Commitment.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 80 | bei Position 1377-1383 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:49:35

A counterfeit “yes” is one in which your counterpart plans on saying “no” but either feels “yes” is an easier escape route or just wants to disingenuously keep the conversation going to obtain more information or some other kind of edge. A confirmation “yes” is generally innocent, a reflexive response to a black-or-white question; it’s sometimes used to lay a trap but mostly it’s just simple affirmation with no promise of action. And a commitment “yes” is the real deal; it’s a true agreement that leads to action, a “yes” at the table that ends with a signature on the contract. The commitment “yes” is what you want, but the three types sound almost the same so you have to learn how to recognize which one is being used.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 81 | bei Position 1385-1387 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:50:29

good negotiators know that their job isn’t to put on a great performance but to gently guide their counterpart to discover their goal as his own.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1432-1432 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:56:09

It’s not about me. We need to persuade from their perspective, not ours.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1432-1433 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:56:18

By starting with their most basic wants.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1433-1433 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:56:38

In every negotiation, in every agreement, the result comes from someone else’s decision.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1434-1436 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:56:49

while we can’t control others’ decisions, we can influence them by inhabiting their world and seeing and hearing exactly what they want.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1436-1437 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:57:05

Though the intensity may differ from person to person, you can be sure that everyone you meet is driven by two primal urges: the need to feel safe and secure, and the need to feel in control.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 84 | bei Position 1438-1439 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:57:33

you’re not going to logically convince them that they’re safe, secure, or in control. Primal needs are urgent and illogical,
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 85 | bei Position 1440-1441 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:58:22

being “nice” in the form of feigned sympathy is often equally as unsuccessful
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 85 | bei Position 1444-1445 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:58:34

Instead of getting inside with logic or feigned smiles, then, we get there by asking for “No.”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 85 | bei Position 1444-1447 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:58:47

Instead of getting inside with logic or feigned smiles, then, we get there by asking for “No.” It’s the word that gives the speaker feelings of safety and control. “No” starts conversations and creates safe havens to get to the final “Yes” of commitment. An early “Yes” is often just a cheap, counterfeit dodge.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 86 | bei Position 1455-1455 | Hinzugefügt am Freitag, 4. November 2022 23:59:44

“NO” IS PROTECTION
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 86 | bei Position 1458-1460 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:00:33

Whenever we negotiate, there’s no doubt we want to finish with a “Yes.” But we mistakenly conflate the positive value of that final “Yes” with a positive value of “Yes” in general. And because we see “No” as the opposite of “Yes,” we then assume that “No” is always a bad thing.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 86 | bei Position 1458-1461 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:00:38

Whenever we negotiate, there’s no doubt we want to finish with a “Yes.” But we mistakenly conflate the positive value of that final “Yes” with a positive value of “Yes” in general. And because we see “No” as the opposite of “Yes,” we then assume that “No” is always a bad thing. Nothing could be further from the truth.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 86 | bei Position 1458-1463 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:01:06

Whenever we negotiate, there’s no doubt we want to finish with a “Yes.” But we mistakenly conflate the positive value of that final “Yes” with a positive value of “Yes” in general. And because we see “No” as the opposite of “Yes,” we then assume that “No” is always a bad thing. Nothing could be further from the truth. Saying “No” gives the speaker the feeling of safety, security, and control. You use a question that prompts a “No” answer, and your counterpart feels that by turning you down he has proved that he’s in the driver’s seat. Good negotiators welcome—even invite—a solid “No” to start, as a sign that the other party is engaged and thinking.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 86 | bei Position 1458-1464 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:01:18

Whenever we negotiate, there’s no doubt we want to finish with a “Yes.” But we mistakenly conflate the positive value of that final “Yes” with a positive value of “Yes” in general. And because we see “No” as the opposite of “Yes,” we then assume that “No” is always a bad thing. Nothing could be further from the truth. Saying “No” gives the speaker the feeling of safety, security, and control. You use a question that prompts a “No” answer, and your counterpart feels that by turning you down he has proved that he’s in the driver’s seat. Good negotiators welcome—even invite—a solid “No” to start, as a sign that the other party is engaged and thinking. Gun for a “Yes” straight off the bat, though, and your counterpart gets defensive, wary, and skittish.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 88 | bei Position 1490-1490 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:04:18

“No” is not failure. Used strategically it’s an answer that opens the path forward
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 88 | bei Position 1490-1491 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:04:25

“No” is not failure. Used strategically it’s an answer that opens the path forward. Getting to the point where you’re no longer horrified by the word “No” is a liberating moment that every negotiator needs to reach.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 88 | bei Position 1492-1493 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:04:47

let’s undress “No.” It’s a reaffirmation of autonomy.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 88 | bei Position 1494-1495 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:04:57

In fact, “No” often opens the discussion up. The sooner you say “No,” the sooner you’re willing to see options and opportunities that you were blind to previously.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 89 | bei Position 1502-1510 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:06:25

“No” has a lot of skills. ■​“No” allows the real issues to be brought forth; ■​“No” protects people from making—and lets them correct—ineffective decisions; ■​“No” slows things down so that people can freely embrace their decisions and the agreements they enter into; ■​“No” helps people feel safe, secure, emotionally comfortable, and in control of their decisions; ■​“No” moves everyone’s efforts forward.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 90 | bei Position 1525-1525 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:07:41

Jim Camp’s book Start with NO
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 91 | bei Position 1545-1547 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:10:10

There is a big difference between making your counterpart feel that they can say “No” and actually getting them to say it. Sometimes, if you’re talking to somebody who is just not listening, the only way you can crack their cranium is to antagonize them into “No.”
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 91 | bei Position 1545-1548 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:10:21

There is a big difference between making your counterpart feel that they can say “No” and actually getting them to say it. Sometimes, if you’re talking to somebody who is just not listening, the only way you can crack their cranium is to antagonize them into “No.” One great way to do this is to mislabel one of the other party’s emotions or desires.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 91 | bei Position 1550-1551 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:10:40

Another way to force “No” in a negotiation is to ask the other party what they don’t want.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 91 | bei Position 1554-1556 | Hinzugefügt am Samstag, 5. November 2022 00:11:43

If despite all your efforts, the other party won’t say “No,” you’re dealing with people who are indecisive or confused or who have a hidden agenda. In cases like that you have to end the negotiation and walk away.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)

- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 92 | bei Position 1562-1563 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 6. November 2022 23:26:22

this one-sentence email encapsulates the best of “No”-oriented questions and plays on your counterpart’s natural human aversion to loss.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 92 | bei Position 1562-1564 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 6. November 2022 23:26:29

this one-sentence email encapsulates the best of “No”-oriented questions and plays on your counterpart’s natural human aversion to loss. The “No” answer the email demands offers the other party the feeling of safety and the illusion of control while encouraging them to define their position and explain it to you.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 92 | bei Position 1564-1566 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 6. November 2022 23:26:52

Just as important, it makes the implicit threat that you will walk away on your own terms. To stop that from happening—to cut their losses and prove their power—the other party’s natural inclination is to reply immediately and disagree.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Ihre Markierung auf Seite 93 | bei Position 1570-1571 | Hinzugefügt am Sonntag, 6. November 2022 23:27:16

CHAPTER 5 TRIGGER THE TWO WORDS THAT IMMEDIATELY TRANSFORM ANY NEGOTIATION
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Deine Markierung auf Seite 97 | bei Position 1628-1631 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 10. November 2022 23:26:55

If you successfully take someone up the Behavioral Change Stairway, each stage attempting to engender more trust and more connection, there will be a breakthrough moment when unconditional positive regard is established and you can begin exerting influence.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Deine Markierung auf Seite 97 | bei Position 1615-1617 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 10. November 2022 23:27:04

Behavioral Change Stairway Model (BCSM). The model proposes five stages—active listening, empathy, rapport, influence, and behavioral change—that take any negotiator from listening to influencing behavior.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Deine Markierung auf Seite 97 | bei Position 1618-1619 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 10. November 2022 23:27:17

real change can only come when a therapist accepts the client as he or she is—an approach known as unconditional positive regard.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Deine Markierung auf Seite 97 | bei Position 1620-1622 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 10. November 2022 23:27:32

for most of us the positive regard we experience is conditional, we develop a habit of hiding who we really are and what we really think, instead calibrating our words to gain approval but disclosing little. Which is why so few social interactions lead to actual behavior change.
==========
Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
- Deine Markierung auf Seite 98 | bei Position 1634-1634 | Hinzugefügt am Donnerstag, 10. November 2022 23:28:04

the sweetest two words in any negotiation are actually “That’s right.”

Never Split the Difference (Voss, Chris)
